"John Mayall, British Blues-Rock Legend and 2024 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductee, Dies at 90"}, "summary": {"eng": "Musician John Mayall, often referred to the \"godfather of the British blues,\" whose bands of the late '60s and early '70s featured some of the most notable rock instrumentalists of the era, died Monday at home in California, according to a statement posted by his family on his social media accounts. He was 90.\n\nAmong the fans and organizations posting condolences was the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, which was set to induct him into its ranks in October.\n\nNo cause of death was given in the family's"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "London"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "wgt": 83}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "wgt": 79}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Bands_and_Artists", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Bands and Artists", "wgt": 79}, {"uri": "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 98}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 176}, "sentiment": 0.192156862745098, "breakingScore": 0.288376145290101}
{"uri": "2024-07-432233936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:38:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:38:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9450980424880981, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_8e46a086-dfef-54e0-a0e7-3337829df39d.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician who influenced a generation of rock heroes from Eric Clapton to Mick Fleetwood, died at his California home.\n\nLONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1764705882352942, "wgt": 241, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-432315208", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:54:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:54:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9372549057006836, "url": "https://wgntv.com/news/deans-list/ap-john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nAmong this year's new members of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, he is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; and Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat.\n\nClapton and McVie both played on the 1966 release \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" which Rolling Stone magazine has ranked among the 500 greatest albums.\n\n\"He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented musicians,\" Mick Jagger wrote on X, adding that it was Mayall who recommended Taylor as a replacement in 1969 for founding Stones guitarist Brian Jones, \"ushering in a new era\" for the band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nThough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" markeda permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "wgntv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGN-TV"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wgntv.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2078431372549019, "wgt": 239, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-431494976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "01:57:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T01:57:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/entertainment/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_54e478ef-77e2-55cd-8fbf-f036bd83e338.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died\n\nLONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. THIS MATERIAL MAY NOT BE PUBLISHED, BROADCAST, REWRITTEN OR REDISTRIBUTED.", "source": {"uri": "channel3000.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Channel 3000"}, "authors": [{"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1607843137254903, "wgt": 238, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8241120852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:17:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:17:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:17:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.abcactionnews.com/news/national-news/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "FILE - British Blues pioneer John Mayall performs with this band the Bluesbreakers at the Deutsche Museum in Munich, West Germany, on Jan. 21, 1970. Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, died Monday, July 22, 2024, at his home in California. He was 90.\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nWith Joe Biden out and Kamala Harris in as the Democratic Party nominee, ABC Action News anchor Paul LaGrone took to the streets of Tampa to get your voice on the campaign shakeup.\n\nYour Voice | How do you feel about the presidential race\n\nSalt Lake City will host the 2034 Winter Olympics\n\nAssociated Press\n\n6:36 AM, Jul 24, 2024\n\nSunday, July 21 was the hottest day ever measured on Earth\n\nScripps News Staff\n\n10:41 PM, Jul 23, 2024\n\nCould Harris beat Trump? Historian who's predicted past elections weighs in\n\nAlex Arger\n\n10:19 PM, Jul 23, 2024\n\nNew data set shows the nationwide impacts of US climate disasters\n\nVanessa Misciagna\n\n9:42 PM, Jul 23, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-21", "textStart": 7134, "textEnd": {"uri": "8241470675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:52:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:52:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:51:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Entertainment/498426/John-Mayall-tireless-and-influential-British-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90 - Entertainment News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press FILE - English blues singer John Mayall performs with his band The Bluesbreakers, on the stage of the Miles Davis hall during the 42nd Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux, Switzerland, late Monday, July 7, 2008. Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, died Monday, July 22, 2024, at his home in California. He was 90. (Sandro Campardo/Keystone via AP, File)\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nAmong this year's new members of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, he is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; and Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat.\n\nClapton and McVie both played on the 1966 release \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" which Rolling Stone magazine has ranked among the 500 greatest albums.\n\n\"He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented musicians,\" Mick Jagger wrote on X, adding that it was Mayall who recommended Taylor as a replacement in 1969 for founding Stones guitarist Brian Jones, \"ushering in a new era\" for the band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nThough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" markeda permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", "type": "person", {"uri": "2024-07-431449498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:16:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:16:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T19:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/entertainment/articles/2024-07-23/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90", "title": "John Mayall, Tireless and Influential British Blues Pioneer, Dies at 90", "body": "FILE - English blues singer John Mayall performs with his band The Bluesbreakers, on the stage of the Miles Davis hall during the 42nd Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux, Switzerland, late Monday, July 7, 2008. Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, died Monday, July 22, 2024, at his home in California. He was 90. (Sandro Campardo/Keystone via AP, File)\n\nLONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-07", "textStart": 197, "textEnd": 209}], "sentiment": 0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 238, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8240383432", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "02:05:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T02:05:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T02:05:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-24/john-mayall-died-90-bluesbreakers-guitarist-obituary/104135046", "title": "John Mayall, blues icon who fostered careers of Eric Clapton and members of Fleetwood Mac, dies at 90", "body": "He was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton, is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death on Tuesday, local time, saying the musician died on Monday at his home in California.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nAt various times, the Bluesbreakers included Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with The Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nThough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins.\n\nHe received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down. He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton, is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on November 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up\".\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, Blues Alone.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined the Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen\".\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career\".\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his songwriting abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude that Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released The Turning Point, arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic line-up including Mark and Almond. Room to Move, a song from that album, was a frequent audience favourite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990.\n\nOne consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Work/Company_Loyalty", "label": "https://live-production.wcms.abc-cdn.net.au/867705e8123c2027792c57d3ac863e1a?impolicy=wcms_watermark_news&cropH=2347&cropW=4172&xPos=0&yPos=905&width=862&height=485&imformat=generic", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3647058823529412, "wgt": 237, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-431448882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:15:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:15:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T23:47:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.wral.com/story/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/21538037/", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "wral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WRAL"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", "type": "person", "score": 5, {"uri": "8240321565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:51:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:51:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:50:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2024/07/23/john-mayall-dead-influential-british-blues-pioneer-was-90-obituary", "title": "John Mayall, influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. {"uri": "8240337079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "01:10:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T01:10:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T01:09:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/music/article/2024/jul/23/john-mayall-blues-dies", "title": "John Mayall, pioneering figure of British blues, dies aged 90", "body": "Influential musician, whose band the Bluesbreakers played leading role in 60s blues revival, dies at home in California\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death, saying the musician died on Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band - who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nThough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination for Wake Up Call and a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down. He also won official recognition in Britain with an OBE in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class, and his 1966 album Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton, is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall was born on 29 November 1933 in the Cheshire town of Macclesfield, south of Manchester. Sounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said: \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues\", but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene. The Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen\".\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: he disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career\".\n\nClapton added: \"I think he's a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness.\"\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the 70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for DownBeat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed - shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage.
