{"uri": "2024-07-431442580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:00:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:00:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T23:58:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/entertainment/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90-1.6975113", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8240272735", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "23:54:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T23:54:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T23:51:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/john-mayall-tireless-influential-british-234708547.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer {"uri": "8240318055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:46:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:46:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:46:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/07/24/john-mayall-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-aged-90/", "title": "John Mayall, influential British blues pioneer, dies aged 90", "body": "Mayall is credited with playing an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died aged 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said the musician died Monday at his home in California.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nMayall is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nAt various times, the Bluesbreakers included Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac, Mick Taylor, who played for five years with the Rolling Stones, Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down and was made an OBE in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nBorn on November 29, 1933, in Macclesfield, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 he aimed to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands.\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8242037711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:38:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:38:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:38:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/07/24/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/", "title": "Remembering John Mayall: The Influential British Blues Musician - GV Wire", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nRelated Story: Comedian Bob Newhart, Deadpan Master of Sitcoms and Telephone Monologues, Dies ...\n\nAmong this year's new members of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, he is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; and Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat.\n\nClapton and McVie both played on the 1966 release \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" which Rolling Stone magazine has ranked among the 500 greatest albums.\n\n\"He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented musicians,\" Mick Jagger wrote on X, adding that it was Mayall who recommended Taylor as a replacement in 1969 for founding Stones guitarist Brian Jones, \"ushering in a new era\" for the band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nThough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nRelated Story: James Sikking, Star of 'Hill Street Blues' and 'Doogie ...\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nRelated Story: Shannen Doherty, 'Beverly Hills, 90210' Star, Dies at 53\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" markeda permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "gvwire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GV Wire"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@gvwire.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "British blues"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Fleetwood", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Mick Fleetwood"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Clapton", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Eric Clapton"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blues", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Blues"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McVie", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John McVie"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Taylor", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Mick Taylor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolling_Stone", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Rolling Stone"}}, {"uri": "https://gvwire.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/24151955/image-2024-07-24T151925.142.jpeg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", {"uri": "2024-07-431513992", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "02:35:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T02:35:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T02:33:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.koco.com/article/john-mayall-death-obit/61681000", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.A statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.He is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.Mayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"A small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"Known for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.He was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.Mayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"Mayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.Sounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"His father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.Mayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"The piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"Mayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.The Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.Mayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"Mayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.Clapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.Mayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.Mick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"", "source": {"uri": "koco.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KOCO5"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8240327769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "01:00:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T01:00:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:57:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/john-mayall-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-aged-90-1653455.html", "title": "John Mayall, influential British blues pioneer, dies aged 90 | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died aged 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said the musician died Monday at his home in California.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nMayall is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nAt various times, the Bluesbreakers included Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac, Mick Taylor, who played for five years with the Rolling Stones, Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down and was made an OBE in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nBorn on November 29, 1933, in Macclesfield, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 he aimed to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands.\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "image": "https://img.resized.co/breaking--mayall-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-aged-90.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, {"uri": "8240721353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:14:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:14:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:10:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2801417/", "title": "John Mayall, Tireless and Influential Pioneer of British Blues, Dies at 90ExBulletin - ExBulletin", "body": "English blues singer John Mayall performs with his band The Bluesbreakers, on stage at Miles Davis Hall during the 42nd Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux, Switzerland, July 7, 2008.\n\nLONDON John Mayall, the British blues musician whose Bluesbreakers formed the foundations of Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement posted on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. The health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally brought peace to one of the world's greatest road warriors, the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping to develop the English version of Chicago-style urban rhythm and blues that played a significant role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who later formed the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of music he first heard on his father's 78 rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a bandleader and I know what I want to play in my band and who my good friends are,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's really a family. It's really a small thing.\"\n\nA small success that endures. Although Mayall never achieved the fame of some of his illustrious former students, he was still performing in his late 80s, playing his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition bothered him a little, and he was not shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit, I've never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a single article about me,\" he said in a 2013 interview with the Santa Barbara Independent. \"I'm still an underground artist.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall was nominated for a Grammy for \"Wake Up Call\" with guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down. He also gained official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame's Class of 2024, and his 1966 album, Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton, is considered one of the finest British blues albums.\n\nMayall was once asked whether he continued to play because there was demand or simply to show that he could still do it.\n\nFortunately, the demand is there. But it's really not for those two reasons, it's just for the love of music, he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. I just get together with these guys and we work out.\n\nMayall was born on 29 November 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester, in central England.\n\nEchoing the voice of the down-on-his-luck bluesman, Mayall once said: \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his piano boogie-woogie records captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time, one year on the left hand, one year on the right, so I wouldn't get confused.\n\nThe piano was his primary instrument, but he also played guitar and harmonica, all the while singing in a characteristically strained voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played every other instrument on his 1967 album, Blues Alone.\n\nMayall has often been considered the father of British blues, but when he moved to London in 1962, his aim was to immerse himself in the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon, among others, were drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers relied on a fluid community of musicians who came and went from different bands. Mayall's greatest achievement was Clapton, who had left the Yardbirds and joined the Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later recalled that Mayall had the most incredible record collection I've ever seen.\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's whims: he disappeared a few months after joining the group, then reappeared later that year, pushing aside newly arrived Peter Green, then left permanently in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which enjoyed meteoric commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, admitted that to some extent I used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\n\n\"I think he's a great musician. I admire and respect his perseverance,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his songwriting abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, appreciated the great latitude Mayall gave his soloists.\n\n\"You would have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could also make as many mistakes as you wanted.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon marked a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released The Turning Point, arguably his most successful album, featuring an atypical four-piece acoustic lineup, including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move\", a song from this album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nBy the 1970s, Mayall was at a personal low, but he continued to tour, performing over 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I did most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in a 1990 interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that nearly broke one of Mayall's heels and left him limping.\n\nIt was an incident that made me stop drinking, Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the lineup changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was retiring the Bluesbreakers name permanently, and in 2013 he led the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", "type": "person", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2008-07-07", "textStart": 169, "textEnd": 181}], "sentiment": 0.2627450980392156, "wgt": 234, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8240280040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:08:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:08:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:00:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/john-mayall-tireless-influential-british-234708547.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "A statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", "type": "person", "score": 5, {"uri": "8241190589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:02:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:02:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:59:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/entertainment-news-john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90-6134271.html", "title": "Entertainment News | John Mayall, Tireless and Influential British Blues Pioneer, Dies at 90 | LatestLY", "body": "London, Jul 24 (AP) John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died.\n\nHe was 90.\n\nAlso Read | Suriya's 'Kanguva', Tovino Thomas' 'Identity', Allu Arjun's 'Pushpa 2' - A Look at the 11 Most-Awaited South Films of 2024!.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nAlso Read | 'Bigg Boss OTT 3' Makers To Take Action Over Obscene 'Doctored Clip' Featuring Armaan Malik and Kritika Malik's Intimate Moment.\n\nAt various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on November 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons. {"uri": "2024-07-432243368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:47:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:47:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://nptelegraph.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_64950ce5-8324-52ea-b65f-c8900fec8b5c.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died\n\nLONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nAs police kill Native Americans on this reservation, families left afraid and in the dark Seven veterans honored with Quilts of Valor at North Platte Pow Wow Nebraska's first Lego store could be opening soon. Here's what to expect. 18-year-old Ogallala teen dies in wreck at dead end of A Street Thursday This Nebraska couple run a senior dog sanctuary Teen accused of causing train derailment near Bennet before recording it Man dies in train vs. van crash outside Kearney Check out the changes for deer season this fall in Nebraska Former Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse to resign as University of Florida president Letter from the Editor: Megan Kelley has moved from newsroom to classroom and back again North Platte man sentenced to 10 to 15 years for domestic assault For $20,000, and a bit of 'vision,' this rural Nebraska church could be yours 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season North Platte man sentenced to prison term for possession of firearm Tornados, damaged buildings from sever storms reported Tuesday night\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024\n\nChita Rivera\n\nCarl Weathers\n\nWayne Kramer\n\nIan Lavender\n\nToby Keith\n\nHenry Fambrough\n\nBob Edwards\n\nDon Gullett\n\nLefty Driesell\n\nAndreas Brehme\n\nGolden Richards\n\nRichard Lewis\n\nBrian Mulroney\n\nIris Apfel\n\nAndy Russell\n\nEd Ott\n\nChris Mortensen\n\nPaul Alexander\n\nThomas P. {"uri": "8240317526", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:54:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:54:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:45:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13665673/John-Mayall-influential-British-blues-pioneer-dies-aged-90.html", "title": "John Mayall, influential British blues pioneer, dies aged 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died aged 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said the musician died Monday at his home in California.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nMayall is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nJohn Mayall performs in 2008 (AP)\n\nAt various times, the Bluesbreakers included Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac, Mick Taylor, who played for five years with the Rolling Stones, Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down and was made an OBE in 2005.\n\nBritish Blues pioneer John Mayall performs with his band the Bluesbreakers in Munich, West Germany on June 5, 1969 (AP)\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nBorn on November 29, 1933, in Macclesfield, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 he aimed to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nFILE - British Blues pioneer John Mayall performs with this band the Bluesbreakers at the Deutsche Museum in Munich, West Germany, on Jan. 21, 1970. (Claus Hampel/AP)\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands.\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8240986561", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:59:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:59:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:59:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13667147/British-Blues-musician-dies-aged-90.html", "title": "British Blues musician dies aged 90", "body": "The father of British blues John Mayall has died aged 90 after health issues forced him to stop touring. The musician died at his home in California on Monday surrounded by family, a statement on his Instagram page said.\n\nThe British blues pioneer led the Bluesbreakers band that influenced stars including Eric Clapton and Mick Fleetwood . He stopped touring in 2021 because of health issues, which his family referred to when they announced his passing.\n\nIn a statement, they said: 'It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home on July 22, 2024, surrounded by loving family. 'Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. 'John Mayall gave us 90 years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.'\n\nMayall, who was born in Macclesfield and grew up in Cheadle, Greater Manchester, formed the Bluesbreakers in the early 1960s. He has been credited with helping develop a blues revival of the late 1960s and has been described as the 'father of British blues'.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers started out playing at the Marquee Club -- a small and relatively cheap club -- situated at the heart of London 's West End. In 1964, Mayall obtained his first record date with producer Ian Samwell. The band recorded two tracks: 'Crawling Up a Hill' and 'Mr James'.\n\nBut it wasn't until April 1965 when former Yardbirds guitarist Eric Clapton replaced Roger Dean, that Mayall's career really took off. In 1965, with Eric Clapton as their new guitar player, the Bluesbreakers began attracting considerable attention. When Clapton left that summer on a jaunt to Greece, Peter Green -- founder of Fleetwood Mac -- took his place, while Jack Bruce -- of the rock band Cream -- played bass. In November 1965 Clapton returned, and Green departed.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers has been considered a training ground for other major musicians including John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac, Mick Taylor who played with the Rolling Stones, Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band. Mayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records. Although he admitted in an interview with The Guardian that he had 'managed to pick out some pretty special people'.\n\n'I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band - who can be good friends of mine,' Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. 'It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.' Although Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s. 'I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,' he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. 'I'm still an underground performer.'\n\nMayall had a Grammy nomination for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He also received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down. He was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton is considered one of the best British blues albums. He was made an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMayall's father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son. Mayall once said: 'The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.' He learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right -- so 'I wouldn't get all tangled up'.\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone. The Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year. In 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail?
