{"uri": "8241453674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:41:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:41:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:40:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_b67a0adf-d9dd-5694-992c-e16f52483e10.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington teen rebuilds landscape of alma mater for Eagle Scout project Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Flick Fact: That J.D. Vance beard and its McLean County significance? Man struck by gunfire early Saturday in north Normal Video: Springfield woman ducked, apologized before fatal police shooting Update: Canton police say missing 2-year-old has been found alive Police: Bloomington teen ran from crash before drowning in Illinois River Pritzker, Illinois leaders react to Biden leaving presidential race Man held on 9 charges relating to May shootout in Bloomington neighborhood 'Shocked, horrified,' Illinois leaders condemn police killing of Sonya Massey Funerals today for July 23 McLean County Unit 5 OKs pay hikes for nonunion employees Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday afternoon on RT Dunn Drive Ronald & Wanda Coyne U High senior Jeremy Coleman willing his way to volleyball future\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "BBC"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts", "label": "dmoz/Arts", "wgt": 10}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "wgt": "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/67/b67a0adf-d9dd-5694-992c-e16f52483e10/66a0f84b4944c.preview.jpg?crop=1736%2C911%2C7%2C89&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "London"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-23", "textStart": 1708, "textEnd": 1715}], "sentiment": -0.02745098039215688, "wgt": 226, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8241458133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:44:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:44:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:43:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_6e857e17-5a14-58ec-bd75-1e0266b6c3f8.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Ex-Buffalo Sabres captain Kyle Okposo's thank-you letter to city, franchise North Tonawanda's best days seemed to be past. Now it's not only thriving - it's cool The Foxglove Pub in Hamburg is open again ... and this time the owners plan to keep it that way Where to take out-of-town guests to eat around Buffalo Henry Nowak, longtime Buffalo congressman and Canisius basketball star, has died Juicy Burger Bar opening new restaurant on Hamburg waterfront 97 Rock's 'Slick Tom' Tiberi fired over Facebook meme showing Trump in coffin Two charged with making terrorist threats in separate Niagara County cases Three charged following fights at Williamsville's Old Home Days Officials identify woman killed in small plane crash near Youngstown These 10 Buffalo Bills have the most at stake as training camp begins. Take a look Erie County real estate transactions Inside the NHL: A summer look at the Sabres' cap situation, for now and into the future Josh Allen leads a revamped Bills offense in 2024. These five moments are shaping the new approach Religious group accused of cult-like tactics seeks to buy former Catholic seminary in Aurora\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8241438367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:31:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:31:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:30:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_b9706c38-00e1-508f-9d76-8cf19cf911da.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man who had himself banned from Iowa casinos wins jackpot at the Isle Chased out of Buchanan County, Balance music festival coming to Waterloo UPDATE: Man who died in lawnmower accident was Don Bosco teacher State: NewAldaya Lifescapes resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails Teen seriously injured in Dunkerton rollover crash Denver girls' track coach fired for unknown reason despite petition from community Name released in Hudson fatal shooting Interstate traffic shut down for person on bridge College Wrestling: UNI receives major gift toward new training facility Man arrested for knife threats at Waterloo apartment building John Deere will lay off an undetermined number of salaried workers beginning next week UPDATE: 15 year old injured in reported shooting 2024 Iowa Shrine Bowl: North squad downs South in offensive shootout Final work session for proposed merged high school covers athletics, traffic, boundaries High School Baseball: Johnston survives Cedar Falls in 13-inning 4A substate classic\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8241500461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:11:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:11:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:10:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_85103dc4-fc23-50ac-95b0-6298f0e13baf.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8241463230", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:47:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:47:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:46:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://tucson.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_924c43b3-a97e-57b7-9f7f-028d07975f6a.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Lake Powell reaches highest level in more than 3 years Furniture and electronics store closing Tucson locations 46-year-old man shot to death at east side Tucson gas station Buyers of Ram diesel pickups were defrauded, Arizona attorney general says Storm damage seeds debate about Tucson's tree choices Court rejects requiring citizenship proof for some AZ voters in presidential race Woman held against will dies after jump from moving car chased by Pima deputies Two Democrats vie in primary for Pima County treasurer nomination 50 fun events happening in Tucson this weekend July 18-21 \ud83c\udf05\ud83c\udfac Global system IT outage forces closure of Tucson health clinics, urgent cares U of A quietly drops unpopular 'UArizona' moniker U.S. authorities plan to relocate endangered wolves spotted near Flagstaff Woman who died after jumping from car is identified Reggae star Ziggy Marley heading to Tucson No tornado, but powerful storm left swath of damage across Tucson\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. Ruddy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sloan_(band)", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Sloan (band)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurel_Canyon,_Los_Angeles", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Laurel Canyon, Los Angeles"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Associated Press"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "BBC"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Styles", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/In_Memoriam", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/In Memoriam", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Bands_and_Artists", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Bands and Artists", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/tucson.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/24/924c43b3-a97e-57b7-9f7f-028d07975f6a/66a0f84210cc8.preview.jpg?crop=1736%2C911%2C7%2C89&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "London"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-18", "dateEnd": "2024-07-21", "textStart": 1576, "textEnd": 1586}], "sentiment": -0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 224, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8241461874", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:46:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:46:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:45:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_fc6a92d9-5a58-5218-905c-c01b8c335396.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Death Notices Death Notices Death Notices Crash in Shoshone claims life of motorcyclist 2 injured after Sun Valley Tour de Force crash A bank collapses on the Snake River near Burley, threatening eagle nest Twin Falls infant hospitalized after possible drug exposure American Legion roundup: Minico B wins state title, Minico A wins district title Ben Gillette powers Minico B back to American Legion state final A NEW PATH: NFR qualifying bull rider Smith looks for same success in steer wrestling Second time around: Jury finds Kimberly man guilty of video voyeurism DOG DAYS: How 3 Magic Valley football teams are approaching the summer Twin Falls firefighters respond to fire that appeared to start outside home CrossFit Twin Falls -- building hearts, minds and bodies Buhl man dies after front-end loader, pickup truck collide\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. Stafford Chris Simon M. {"uri": "8240322901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:53:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:53:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:52:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_3ee0c071-0c85-5f69-8a1d-858cf5744304.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "AP\n\nLONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington teen rebuilds landscape of alma mater for Eagle Scout project Police: Bloomington teen ran from crash before drowning in Illinois River Flick Fact: That J.D. Vance beard and its McLean County significance? Man struck by gunfire early Saturday in north Normal Update: Canton police say missing 2-year-old has been found alive Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Video: Springfield woman ducked, apologized before fatal police shooting Illinois delegate caught in RNC commotion involving McCarthy, Gaetz Pritzker, Illinois leaders react to Biden leaving presidential race Man held on 9 charges relating to May shootout in Bloomington neighborhood Flick Fact: The LeRoy man who set an Illinois State Police record? Country singer Trace Adkins to perform in Bloomington this fall McLean County Unit 5 OKs pay hikes for nonunion employees 'Shocked, horrified,' Illinois leaders condemn police killing of Sonya Massey Ronald & Wanda Coyne\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your {"uri": "8241495658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:08:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:08:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:07:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://qctimes.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_bee71d1d-d0a6-5e71-96a9-d4fa142f0ad9.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... New business coming to Davenport's former Bed Bath & Beyond Two injured in shooting at NorthPark Mall in Davenport Monday Witnesses describe gunfire at NorthPark Mall that injured 2 Quad-Cities business openings: New furniture store coming to Davenport, other happenings Davenport code enforcement officer quits after argument with boss over Wold-owned duplex Teen arrested in relation to shooting at NorthPark Mall in Davenport Deere rolls back diversity, equity, inclusion initiatives after conservative backlash Several Davenport teens accused of gang crimes; police report group violence down overall Timeless Tickets: East Moline-raised rapper Torrian Ball remembers opening for Lil Durk in 2021 Second person dies after Friday house fire in Riverdale One injured in Scott County motorcycle crash Davenport developer pulls 16-unit central city development at Sixth and Sylvan Iowa nursing home resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails, state says One person found dead during Riverdale house fire early Friday morning Name released in fatal East Moline shooting\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8241532918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:31:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:31:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:31:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://journalstar.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_d855afd1-a525-53e8-aebb-38993c81eccb.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Lincoln restaurant calls it quits after 15 years 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season 'Exhausting, heartbreaking, devastating': Racism at Wayne school pushes family out of Nebraska Former Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse to resign as University of Florida president Fleet Farm backed out of northwest Lincoln development This Nebraska couple runs a senior dog sanctuary just outside of Lincoln Recruiting: New Nebraska football staffer aims for pair of 2026 four-star targets Guatemalan chicken restaurant puts Lincoln, Gretna and Crete on its expansion map Teen accused of causing train derailment near Bennet before recording it Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray sentenced to probation for DUI Is it legal to turn on red traffic arrows in Lincoln? What new Nebraska law says Pedestrian struck by car in west Lincoln dies at hospital, police say Lincoln Animal Control reports first-ever rabies case in a fox 'Death Row:' Nebraska defensive line room embracing new nickname Numerous Lincoln operations affected by global tech outage\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P.
