{"uri": "8241470158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:52:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:52:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:51:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://statesville.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_2549cef5-2e69-5c48-adc8-a92c6eb3625e.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Out of Our Past: Monster tooth found in Cool Spring; Jennings Road opens 2 teens who died in crash during Greensboro police chase had just finished middle school Biden drops out of race, endorses VP Harris after disastrous debate inflamed age concerns From a 17-year-old high school student, Wanda Bustle's career at Iredell Health 'a journey worth every mile!' Iredell sisters arrested on drug charges after traffic stop As police kill Native Americans on this reservation, families left afraid and in the dark Iredell chase ends with crash; one reported dead Biden decision shifts Cooper VP talk into higher gear Thirteen Mitchell cousins attend family reunion Stony Point man, woman facing drug charges in Iredell County Former Statesville Christian coach sentenced on two counts of assaulting female Fayetteville man charged in fatal Iredell County wreck Rotary Club of Greater Statesville honors members at end of Rotary year Enjoy music and fireworks in Alexander County on Saturday Fort Dobbs Artisan Farmers Market moves to new day\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8241443144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:35:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:35:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:34:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_7749266d-eca7-5415-8746-173ad69b21d7.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Roaming Buffalo Outpost moving from Rutherford Road to Marion's North Main Street 2 teens who died after crash during Greensboro police chase had just finished middle school. A 15-year-old also died. Expanded grocery, new mural: Remodeled Marion Walmart shows off renovations McDowell alum, WCU pitcher aims for major league draft in 2025 Marion's splash pad damaged in act of vandalism Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court Marion councilman is delegate to Republican convention in Milwaukee McDowell County man charged with three counts of extortion Avery County woman charged in McDowell for drug crimes Three Lenoir residents charged; More than 400 grams of meth seized Art on Hickory oil tanker truck highlights efforts to prevent veteran suicide What is Soma Church? Hickory pastor talks vision, $4.65 million purchase of former CommScope building As police kill Native Americans on this reservation, families left afraid and in the dark Two NC women charged after 5 dogs found with no food, water or shelter, police say McDowell County to hold strategic plan input session\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Brian Mulroney Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Paul Alexander Thomas P. Stafford Laurent de Brunhoff Obit Angelos Baseball Joe Lieberman Louis Gossett Jr. Jerry Grote Schappell Twins Peter Higgs Ralph Puckett Jr. O.J. {"uri": "8240347710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "01:21:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T01:21:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T01:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/23/metro/john-mayall-tireless-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-90/", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90 - The Boston Globe", "body": "He is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMr. Mayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mr. Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mr. Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mr. Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor, and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMr. Mayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMr. Mayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933, in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mr. Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMr. Mayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mr. Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMr. Mayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mr. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined the Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMr. Mayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mr. Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMr. Mayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mr. Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMr. Mayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude that Mr. Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMr. Mayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mr. Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mr. Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mr. Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mr. Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" he said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mr. Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8240326400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:57:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:57:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:56:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/entertainment/2024/07/24/john-mayall-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-aged-90/", "title": "John Mayall, influential British blues pioneer, dies aged 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died aged 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said the musician died Monday at his home in California.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nMayall is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down and was made an OBE in 2005.\n\nBorn on November 29, 1933, in Macclesfield, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 he aimed to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.", "source": {"uri": "jerseyeveningpost.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8241007428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:11:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:11:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:10:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.syracuse.com/entertainment/2024/07/music-legend-dies-months-before-induction-into-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame.html", "title": "Music legend dies months before induction into Rock and Roll Hall of Fame", "body": "British blues musician John Mayall is dead at age 90, representatives announced Tuesday.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" a statement said.\n\nMayall died Monday at his home in California. A cause of death was not announced.\n\nKnown as the \"godfather of the British blues,\" Mayall was the leader of the Bluesbreakers (sometimes referred to as the Blues Breakers). The influential band featured other legends like Eric Clapton, Peter Green, John McVie, Mick Fleetwood, Harvey Mandel, Larry Taylor, and Mick Taylor.\n\nAccording to the Associated Press, Mayall is credited with developing an English twist on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. He sang and played multiple instruments, including blues harmonica and keyboards. His 1966 album \"Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums of all time.\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton said of Mayall in a 2003 BBC documentary.\n\nMayall's biggest hit in America was '70s FM radio staple \"Room to Move,\" but he didn't reach the same fame levels as some of his contemporaries.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nMayall was nominated for a Grammy Award for \"Wake Up Call,\" featuring Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins, and for his 2022 album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMost recently, Mayall was selected for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 2024 class. His death comes months before the scheduled ceremony in October.\n\nUnder the Bluesbreakers, Mayall was known for relentless touring, performing more than 100 shows a year in the '70s. In 2013, he started performing as the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nGuitar great who co-founded famed rock band dies at 81\n\nSyracuse University alumna who discovered Jackson 5 to be inducted in Rock & Roll Hall of Fame", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8241484376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:01:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:01:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:00:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://missoulian.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_e2dcd81b-ea44-5a63-807e-a96a38396818.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man kills grizzly, hospitalized after encounter in Flathead National Forest The Stables: New restaurant in downtown Missoula next to Cranky Sam UPDATED: Evacuations ordered for new Butler Creek wildfire; Red Flag Warning Fire, reported explosions prompt Missoula officials to close Lions Park Forest Service aware of interested buyer for Holland Lake Lodge Missoula looks to build sidewalks in Westside neighborhood to avoid gentrification Missoula police urge caution after reported downtown sexual assaults Fire restrictions for county, forests, reservation, as fires start and Miller Peak grows USPS to suspend air service delivery in Montana in favor of ground transportation Miller Peak fire near Missoula barely grows ahead of Friday public meeting Fire danger extreme, restrictions ordered as Miller Peak blaze grows 1 dead after officer-involved shooting in Mineral County NorthWestern monitoring Thursday's weather for possible rare power shutoff 3 Montana inmates die in Cascade County Detention Center in 2 weeks Man shot and killed by Mineral County officers was from Missoula\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nPhotos: Notable deaths in 2024 Glynis Johns Adan Canto Bud Harrelson Dejan Milojevic Jack Burke Mary Weiss Norman Jewison Charles Osgood Melanie Safka Chita Rivera Carl Weathers Wayne Kramer Ian Lavender Toby Keith Henry Fambrough Bob Edwards Don Gullett Lefty Driesell Andreas Brehme Golden Richards Richard Lewis Nikolai Ryzhkov Brian Mulroney Akira Toriyama Iris Apfel Andy Russell Ed Ott Chris Mortensen Steve Lawrence Naomi Barber King Paul Alexander Thomas P. {"uri": "8241324563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:20:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:20:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:20:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayall-obituary", "title": "John Mayall 'The Godfather Of British Blues' Has Died", "body": "John Mayall, \"The Godfather Of British Blues,\" has died at age 90. The legendary musician died \"peacefully in his California home\" on Monday, July 22, \"surrounded by loving family.\"\n\nA statement posted to Mayall's website read:\n\n\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by loving family. Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nBorn on November 29, 1933, in Macclesfield, England, Mayall was motivated by his father's record collection and developed a deep love for music from a young age. He taught himself to play piano, guitar and harmonica, driven by blues pioneers like Leadbelly and the boogie-woogie of Albert Ammons and Pete Johnson.\n\nIn the 1960s, Mayall formed the influential John Mayall & The Bluesbreakers. The band served as a proving ground for some of the most notable British blues and rock musicians of the era, including Eric Clapton, Peter Green, Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, Mick Taylor, Jack Bruce, Aynsley Dunbar and many others.\n\nMayall had over 60 albums credited to his name, blending traditional blues with elements of rock and jazz. His soulful vocals, combined with his virtuosity on multiple instruments, earned him critical acclaim and a dedicated fanbase. His music and mentorship influenced countless musicians and helped shape the sound of British blues and rock.\n\nMayall's landmark 1966 album Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton showcased Clapton's impressively skillful musicianship, establishing Mayall as a central figure in the British blues scene. Mayall's signature approach to the blues can be heard on the 1969 live album, The Turning Point, which featured the hit \"Room To Move.\"\n\nThroughout the 1970s and beyond, Mayall continued to experiment and evolve, continuing to blend jazz, rock, and blues in innovative ways. He collaborated with musicians like Blue Mitchell, Red Holloway and Harvey Mandel, leading to the reformation of The Bluesbreakers in the 1980s with guitarists Coco Montoya and Walter Trout revitalized his career, leading to well-received albums like Behind The Iron Curtain and Wake Up Call.\n\nIn 2008, Mayall officially retired The Bluesbreakers name. The following year saw the establishment of a new group with Mayall backed by guitarist Rocky Athas, bassist Greg Rzab and drummer Jay Davenport. This lineup performed live regularly over numerous years and recorded several albums together.\n\nIn 2013, Mayall signed with Forty Below Records and experienced a late-career resurgence, releasing several albums for the label. Mayall's final studio album was 2022's The Sun Is Shining Down. The archival live album, John Mayall's Bluesbreakers Live In 1967 Vol 3 featuring the original members of Fleetwood Mac - Peter Green, Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, was issued last fall.\n\nMayall's contributions to music were recognized with many honors and awards, including induction into the Blues Hall Of Fame and the Rock And Roll Hall Of Fame. In 2005, Mayall was was honored by the British government with appointment as Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE). He continued to perform and record well into his later years, until recent health issues forced Mayall to cease his \"epic road dog days.\"\n\nAccording to Mayall's website:", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-431505948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "02:19:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T02:19:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T02:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/john-mayall-father-of-british-blues-dies-aged-90-13184033", "title": "John Mayall: 'Father of British blues' dies aged 90", "body": "John Mayall was often called the \"father of British blues\" and was credited with playing an important role in the revival of the genre in the late 1960s.\n\nJohn Mayall, the British blues musician whose band was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died aged 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said he died on Monday at his home in California.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nMayall is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s.\n\nRead more:\n\nLast original member Abdul 'Duke' Fakir dies, aged 88\n\nLittle Mix star shares urgent appeal to find missing niece\n\nAt various times, his band the Bluesbreakers included Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac, Mick Taylor, who played for five years with the Rolling Stones, Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013.\n\n\"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nBorn on 29 November, 1933, in Macclesfield, Mayall once said: \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues\" but when he moved to London in 1962 he aimed to soak up the blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands.\n\nHis 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again.\n\nIn 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.", "source": {"uri": "news.sky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sky News"}, {"uri": "2024-07-432463904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:40:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:40:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:36:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/entertainment/article290387674.html", "title": "'Godfather of British Blues'  John Mayall dies at 90 in California", "body": "July 24 (UPI) -- British blues great John Mayall has died in California at the age of 90. Mick Jagger mourned Mayall's passing, calling him a great pioneer of British blues.\n\nA statement on his Instagram account said he passed away Monday.\n\n\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home,\" the statement said. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\"\n\nJagger's statement on his Instagram account said, \"So sad to hear of John Mayall's passing. He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented young musicians, including Mick Taylor - who he recommended to me after Brian Jones died - ushering in a new era for the Stones.\"\n\nIn 1963 Mayall's band the Bluesbreakers, formerly the Blues Syndicate, started performing regularly at London's Marquee Club.\n\nHis first album, John Mayall plays Mayall, was recorded live at West Hampstead R&B Club.\n\nWhile that first recording was not a commercial success. Mayall added Eric Clapton to his band after Clapton left the Yardbirds, releasing the 1966 album Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton.\n\nMayall is in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and his Bluesbreakers band over the years included not only Clapton but also their Stones' Mick Taylor and several members of the future Fleetwood Mac, including John McVie and Mick Fleetwood.\n\nMayall's Instagram account statement added, \"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home... surrounded by his loving family.\"\n\nAfter the Bluesbreakers formed in 1963, the band charted nearly 20 albums from 1968-75.\n\nAmong the band's biggest sellers was 1969's The Turning Point that went gold peaking on the charts at No. 32. The band's best-selling U.S. album was 1970's USA Union that reached No. 22.\n\nMayall was known as \"the Godfather of British Blues.\" Born in 1933, Mayall played guitar, piano and harmonica in his youth.\n\nHe studied graphic design at Manchester Art School, moved to London and formed the Bluesbreakers while in his early thirties.\n\nIn comments to The Guardian in 2014, Mayall said, \"The blues fitted in with the early '60s, the social way of life at the time. It happened here, rather than in America, because at the time, the scene in America was racially segregated-over there, never the twain would meet.\"\n\nMayall formed the Bluesbreakers with McVie, Peter Ward and others after moving to London in 1963.\n\nQueen Elizabeth II made him an OBE, Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire in 2005. He was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame in 2016 and joined the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2024.", "source": {"uri": "myrtlebeachonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MyrtleBeachOnline"}, {"uri": "2024-07-432267847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:10:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:10:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:35:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_d180d680-7a9b-5d31-9607-b4040bce9f06.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "FILE - English blues singer John Mayall performs with his band The Bluesbreakers, on the stage of the Miles Davis hall during the 42nd Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux, Switzerland, late Monday, July 7, 2008. Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, died Monday, July 22, 2024, at his home in California. He was 90.\n\nAP\n\nLONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nUPDATE: Cedar Lake woman killed in Monday's storm remembered as 'rock of the family' Ex-Crown Point real estate agents indicted on charges of $5 million in COVID relief fraud after allegedly spending money on Porsche and country club Northwoods Falls closes in St. John, owners hope temporarily UPDATE: Valpo man identified as motorcyclist killed when SUV reportedly made sudden U-turn Valparaiso tornado confirmed as county calls state in for help Classic car collection lost to fire during power outage Davich: Frankly, this is the best hot dog joint in the Region Mug released of area foster mom charged in smothering death of 10-year-old Report: Man stopped from jumping to I-94 says officer was first to care for him in long time Crown Point man led chase, soiled police vehicle, report says Sunday night house fire draws out several departments NWI Business Ins and Outs: Royale with Cheese, Top of the Morning, Casa Blanca, Estella's Cantina, El Jimador, Jet's Pizza, Wingstop and Wing Snob opening Earlier warnings failed to prevent Valpo sexual assault, charges say Former Lake County councilman could avoid jail time yet again in 3rd domestic battery case Griffin Tobias is eager to learn the 'Brewer way' after his MLB Draft selection\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/523018/british-blues-legend-john-mayall-dies-aged-90", "title": "British blues legend John Mayall dies aged 90", "body": "British blues musician John Mayall - whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a springboard for stars including Eric Clapton - has died aged 90.\n\nThe songwriter died at his home in California on Monday surrounded by his family, a statement on his Instagram page said.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" it said.\n\n\"John Mayall gave us 90 years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain,\" the statement added.\n\nMayall, who was born in Macclesfield and grew up in Manchester, founded the Bluesbreakers in the 1960s.\n\nHe was credited with helping to develop a blues revival among white musicians in England - and has been described as the \"godfather of British blues\".\n\nMayall told the Guardian in 2014 that \"at the time, the scene in America was racially segregated\" - but in Europe and England \"the black blues began to be heard by an audience that was not listening to them in America\".\n\nAfter their 1966 album featuring guitarist Clapton, the Bluesbreakers were acclaimed by music critics as one of the world's most influential blues bands.\n\nThe group also became a training ground for other famous rock musicians including Fleetwood Mac's Peter Green, John McVie and Mick Fleetwood, as well as Mick Taylor of the Rolling Stones - cementing Mayall's reputation as a \"serious talent magnet\".\n\nHe told the Guardian he \"managed to pick out some pretty special people\", choosing band members based on the specific sound he was after.\n\nMayall moved to Los Angeles in 1969 and continued to lead bands, release dozens of albums and tour throughout the US and Europe, according to his biography on the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.\n\nHe was made an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMayall is survived by his six children, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, the family statement said.\n\n\"He is also surrounded with love by his previous wives, Pamela and Maggie, his devoted secretary, Jane, and his close friends,\" it added.\n\n\"We, the Mayall family, cannot thank his fans and long-list of bandmembers enough for the support and love we were blessed to experience secondhand over the last six decades.\"", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, {"uri": "8241530084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:29:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:29:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:29:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://pitchfork.com/news/john-mayall-the-godfather-of-british-blues-dies-at-90/", "title": "John Mayall, the \"Godfather of British Blues,\" Dies at 90", "body": "Mayall nurtured the craft and careers of Eric Clapton, Peter Green, Mick Taylor, and many more\n\nBritish guitarist and Bluesbreakers leader John Mayall has died. Mayall's family announced the news on his official social media accounts, stating that the musician died in his California home on Monday, July 22, \"surrounded by loving family.\" The statement cited unspecified health issues, but did not reveal an exact cause of death. John Mayall was 90 years old.\n\nDubbed \"the Godfather of British Blues,\" John Mayall was a nurturing figure to a slew of musicians at the start of their careers. Mayall formed the Bluesbreakers in the early 1960s after moving to London, and the band's shifting lineup included a post-Yardbirds, pre-Cream Eric Clapton, who recorded with Mayall on the highly influential 1966 LP Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton. When Clapton left to start Cream, he was replaced by eventual Fleetwood Mac guitarist Peter Green and Mick Taylor, who was ultimately snatched up by the Rolling Stones.\n\nBorn in 1933 in Macclesfield, England, Mayall learned guitar, piano, and harmonica while growing up. He also spent time poring through his father's record collection, which included jazz and blues 78s by the likes of Big Bill Broonzy, Leadbelly, and Brownie McGhee. After studying graphic design at Manchester Art School and serving in Korea, Mayall worked in advertising agencies before shifting focus to music full-time.\n\nMayall moved to London and formed the Bluesbreakers in his early thirties, playing regularly around his new city. The Bluesbreakers ultimately caught attention from Decca, and the label offered Mayall a contract in 1964. Mayall released his debut album with the Bluesbreakers, John Mayall Plays John Mayall, in 1965. One year later, Clapton replaced the band's guitarist Roger Dean.\n\nMayall was a central figure in the narrative of young white British rockers who were fascinated with Black blues musicians from the Mississippi Delta. \"The blues fitted in with the early '60s, the social way of life at the time,\" Mayall told The Guardian in 2014. \"It happened here, rather than in America, because at the time, the scene in America was racially segregated -- over there, never the twain would meet.\"\n\nMayall's output during the 1960s and 1970s was dense, and the prolific artist continued at this pace for decades. In 2013, Mayall experienced a late-career renaissance when he signed to Forty Below Records, releasing a number of studio albums before his death. It was during this fruitful period that Mayall was inducted into Blues Hall of Fame (in 2016).\n\nMayall retired from touring in 2022, but continued releasing records up until last year, with the third installment of his Live in 1967 series, which features Peter Green, Mick Fleetwood, and John McVie.", "source": {"uri": "pitchfork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pitchfork"}, "authors": "dmoz/Business/Arts_and_Entertainment/Music", "label": "dmoz/Business/Arts and Entertainment/Music", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Collecting", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Collecting", "wgt": "https://media.pitchfork.com/photos/66a05c4df6726f52a05504b7/16:9/w_1280,c_limit/John-Mayall.jpg?mbid=social_retweet", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-22", "textStart": 300, "textEnd": 307}], "sentiment": 0.08235294117647052, "wgt": 217, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8240810939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:17:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:17:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:10:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/british-blues-pioneer-john-mayall-031516480.html", "title": "British blues pioneer John Mayall dies aged 90", "body": "British blues musician John Mayall OBE - whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a springboard for stars including Eric Clapton - has died aged 90.\n\nThe songwriter died at his home in California on Monday surrounded by his family, a statement on his Instagram page said.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" it said.\n\n\"John Mayall gave us 90 years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain,\" the statement added.\n\nJohn Mayall was born on 29 November 1933 in the town of Macclesfield in Cheshire.\n\nHis father, Murray, was a talented guitarist and jazz enthusiast and the young Mayall was quickly drawn towards the sound of the blues musicians from the Mississippi Delta.\n\nWhile in his teens, he completed a George Formby Teach Yourself Ukulele course, as well as teaching himself how to play piano.\n\nHe did his National Service in the Army, which included a tour of duty in Korea, before enrolling at Manchester College of Art\n\nMayall quickly gained a reputation as something of an eccentric, building a massive treehouse in his grandparents' back garden, where he lived with his fiancee Pamela.\n\nHe had also bought himself an electric guitar and begun playing with a series of local bands, something he continued to do when he found full-time employment in a local commercial art studio.\n\nIn 1956 he formed the Powerhouse Four, which made something of a name for itself at local dances.\n\nHe joined a band called Blues Syndicate in 1962, which was heavily influenced by Alexis Korner, whose Blues Incorporated was pioneering what would become the 1960s British blues revival.\n\nKorner persuaded Mayall to move to London and take up music as a full-time career. He also introduced Mayall to key contacts on the London club scene and helped him to find gigs.\n\nIn 1963 Mayall's band, now renamed the Bluesbreakers, began regular performances at the Marquee Club, a venue that would prove the springboard for many famous bands including the Rolling Stones and the Who.\n\nA canny businessman, Mayall would often stand outside the venue counting audience numbers to ensure he received a fair share of the ticket money.\n\nMayall was already showing himself expert at spotting talented musicians and his line-up featured John McVie on bass, who would later help form Fleetwood Mac.\n\nHis debut album, John Mayall plays John Mayall, was released in 1965, a live set recorded at a West Hampstead R&B club. The album was not a success and his short-term contract with Decca expired.\n\nAt the same time he recruited Eric Clapton, who had just quit the Yardbirds over their decision to abandon the blues for a more commercial style.\n\nThe presence of Clapton, already an acknowledged star, raised the profile of Mayall's band.\n\nHowever, the frequent arrival and departure of musicians began to dog the Bluesbreakers.\n\nClapton made an unannounced three-month trip to Greece in August 1965, leaving Mayall with the problem of finding a new guitarist.\n\nHis troubles multiplied in October when bassist John McVie was fired, because of his heavy drinking; he was replaced by Jack Bruce.\n\nMayall finally found a guitarist in Peter Green, who spent just three days as a Bluesbreaker before Eric Clapton returned and Green was summarily dismissed.\n\nAt the same time Jack Bruce walked out after a row over his wages and Mayall was forced to rehire John McVie.\n\nIn March 1966, Decca was persuaded to re-sign the Bluesbreakers and they recorded what would be Mayall's first studio album.\n\nDetermined to cash in on the popularity of his talented guitarist, the album was entitled, Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton.\n\nFans would later dub it The Beano Album because of the comic Clapton is shown reading on the record cover.\n\nThe album was well received, reaching sixth place in the charts and providing Mayall with the commercial breakthrough that had previously eluded him.\n\nThe album was still riding high when Clapton announced he was quitting to form Cream with Jack Bruce and Ginger Baker.\n\nMayall persuaded an initially reluctant Peter Green to rejoin the band and he featured as the guitarist on Mayall's next album, Hard Road, released in 1967.\n\nIt was to be Green's only appearance on a Bluesbreakers album, the cover of which featured a painting of the band done by Mayall himself.\n\nThe band's line-up continued to change as musicians left for other projects and Mayall discovered new talent.\n\nMick Fleetwood, Aynsley Dunbar, Mick Taylor and Keef Hartley were just some of the names that passed through the band during 1967 although many had quit by the time Mayall released a solo album, The Blues Alone\n\nEric Clapton once commented: \"John Mayall has actually run an incredibly great school for musicians.\"\n\nA strict disciplinarian, Mayall ruthlessly fired band members who he felt were not up to his exacting standards.\n\nIn 1968 the band began a US tour which featured a gig at the legendary Fillmore West in San Francisco alongside Jimi Hendrix.\n\nFollowing the release of Blues from Laurel Canyon in April 1969, Mayall dropped the Bluesbreakers name and his new line-up experimented with playing without drums.\n\nThe acoustic album, The Turning Point, recorded at the Fillmore East in New York by the new line-up, earned Mayall's only gold disc.\n\nThe seventies saw Mayall move to live in the United States, and form a series of bands with American musicians.\n\nHe moved away from the electric blues that had made his name, and began experimenting with funk, pop and jazz.\n\nHe continued to tour in the UK, however, often backing US blues legends such as John Lee Hooker and Sonny Boy Williamson.\n\nIn 1979 a fire destroyed his home in Laurel Canyon and he lost his master recordings, his diaries and much of his career memorabilia.\n\nThe influence of the blues had declined in the UK but, by 1982, Mayall decided the time was right to re-form the Bluesbreakers.\n\nJohn McVie and Mick Taylor rejoined their old boss for a short time and the enthusiastic reception received by the band encouraged Mayall to put together a more permanent line-up.\n\nMayall continued to tour and record throughout the 1990s and the arrival of Texas guitarist Buddy Whittington in 1993 added a new dimension to the band's sound.\n\nIn 2003 Mayall celebrated his 70th birthday with a concert in Liverpool that featured some of his former musicians including Eric Clapton and Mick Taylor.\n\nIn a career spanning seven decades, John Mayall released more than 50 albums and included some of the foremost musicians of the day in a bewildering series of line-ups.\n\nHe never achieved huge commercial success in his own right but his dedication to keeping the blues alive was a major influence on the rock explosion of the 60s and 70s.\n\nMayall was credited with helping to develop a blues revival among white musicians in England - and has been described as the \"godfather of British blues\".\n\nMayall told the Guardian in 2014 that \"at the time, the scene in America was racially segregated\" - but in Europe and England \"the black blues began to be heard by an audience that was not listening to them in America\".\n\nAfter their 1966 album featuring guitarist Clapton, the Bluesbreakers were acclaimed by music critics as one of the world's most influential blues bands.\n\nHe told the Guardian he \"managed to pick out some pretty special people\", choosing band members based on the specific sound he was after.\n\nHe was made an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nMayall is survived by his six children, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, the family statement said.\n\n\"He is also surrounded with love by his previous wives, Pamela and Maggie, his devoted secretary, Jane, and his close friends,\" it added.\n\n\"We, the Mayall family, cannot thank his fans and long-list of bandmembers enough for the support and love we were blessed to experience secondhand over the last six decades.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", "type": "person", "score": 5, {"uri": "8241308173", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:11:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:11:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:10:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.masslive.com/entertainment/2024/07/legendary-blues-musician-dies-months-before-rock-roll-hall-of-fame-induction.html", "title": "Music legend referred to as 'Godfather of British Blues' dies at 90", "body": "John Mayall, a music legend often referred to as the \"Godfather of British Blues,\" has died just months before he was supposed to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in October. He was 90.\n\nThe blues musician died at his California home Monday, July 22 \"surrounded by his loving family,\" according to a post from the late singer's Instagram.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post reads. \"Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nMayall, who was among this year's inductees for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, was born on Nov. 29, 1933. He grew up in a village not too far from Manchester, England, the musician's biography states.\n\nIn the 1960s, Mayall formed his band called John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers, sometimes referred to as the Blues Breakers.\n\nThe band featured some of the most famous blues/rock musicians like Eric Clapton, Peter Green, John McVie, Mick Fleetwood, Harvey Mandel, Larry Taylor and Mick Taylor.\n\nMayall is credited with developing an English twist on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s, the Associated Press reported. His 1966 album \"Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums of all time.\n\nMayall also had success in the United States with the 1969 singles \"Room to Move\" and \"Don't Waste My Time.\" The latter peaked at No. 81 on the Billboard Hot 100.\n\nA singer, guitarist, harmonica player and keyboardist, Mayall remained an active musician until his death, releasing his last studio album \"The Sun Is Shining Down\" in 2022.\n\nThe album earned Mayall a Grammy nomination for Best Traditional Blues Album at 65th annual Grammy Awards. This was his second Grammy nomination overall.\n\nMayall also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nThe musician leaves behind his six children, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, the Instagram post states.\n\n\"We, the Mayall family, cannot thank his fans and long-list of bandmembers enough for the support and love we were blessed to experience secondhand over the last six decades,\" the post concludes.", "source": {"uri": "masslive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MassLive"}, "authors": [],
