{"uri": "8240910860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:13:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:13:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:12:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.northwichguardian.co.uk/news/24472501.mick-jagger-leads-tributes-cheshir-born-music-icon/", "title": "Tributes pour in following death of Cheshire-born blues icon", "body": "TRIBUTES have poured in following the death of a Cheshire-born music legend.\n\nJohn Mayall, known as 'the godfather of British blues', has died aged 90.\n\nHe was perhaps best known for his influential band, the Bluesbreakers, which was a training ground for superstars such as Eric Clapton and Mick Fleetwood.\n\nA statement shared on his Instagram announced Mayall died on Monday (July 22) at his home in California, surrounded by his family.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" read the post.\n\n\"John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nFollowing the announcement, tributes have been paid from across the music world.\n\nRolling Stones frontman Mick Jagger said: \"So sad to hear of John Mayall's passing.\n\n\"He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented young musicians, including Mick Taylor - who he recommended to me after Brian Jones died - ushering in a new era for the Stones.\"\n\nSteve Hackett, lead guitarist of Genesis, said: \"I'm very sad to hear about the death of John Mayall.\n\n\"He was a true champion of the blues.\n\n\"He remains a huge inspiration to me and a legion of other musicians.\"\n\nMayall was born on November 29, 1933, in Macclesfield.\n\nHe once said: \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nWhile piano was his main instrument, he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers first formed in 1963 and over the years helped launch the careers of several musical icons, including Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played for five years with the Rolling Stones; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was nominated for a Grammy for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins.\n\nHe received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down and was made an OBE in 2005.\n\nMayall was included in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame class of 2024 and was due to be inducted later this year.\n\n\"2024 Inductee John Mayall was the godfather of British blues,\" read a tribute from the awards.\n\n\"As a singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and bandleader, Mayall displayed a talent for mentoring gifted young musicians, many of whom he recruited for his groundbreaking band the Bluesbreakers.\n\n\"With a rugged individuality and distinctive voice and style, he made visionary recordings that expanded the reach of the blues without ever watering them down.\n\n\"Mayall exerted a major influence on rock and roll, inspiring countless musicians and fans with a lifetime's worth of unforgettable and influential music.\"", "source": {"uri": "northwichguardian.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Northwich Guardian - Beta site"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8241766119", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:19:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13668789/Mick-Jagger-Eric-Clapton-lead-tributes-father-British-blues-John-Mayall-death-aged-90-Clapton-thanks-musician-rescuing-oblivion.html", "title": "Jagger and Clapton lead tributes to John Mayall after his death", "body": "The musician died at his home in California on Monday, surrounded by family\n\nSir Mick Jagger and Eric Clapton have led the tributes to the 'father of British blues' John Mayall after his death aged 90.\n\nThe musician died at his home in California on Monday surrounded by family, a statement on his Instagram page said.\n\nThe British blues pioneer led the Bluesbreakers band that influenced stars including Clapton and Mick Fleetwood.\n\nToday, Clapton posted an emotional video to X in which he thanked the Blues legend for rescuing him from 'oblivion'.\n\nRolling Stones frontman Sir Mick told how Mayall had helped his band in 'ushering in a new era for the Stones' as the band's guitarist Ronnie Wood called him a 'musical trailblazer for all of us'.\n\nMayall stopped touring in 2021 because of health issues, which his family referred to when they announced his passing.\n\nBritish Blues pioneer John Mayall (pictured during a concert in Milan in 2015) has died aged 90\n\nJohn Mayall (pictured) in London, March 4, 1971\n\nEric Clapton paid tribute to Mayall in an emotional video in which he told how he had rescued him from 'oblivion'\n\nRolling Stones bandmates Sir Mick Jagger and Ronnie Wood paid tribute to Mayall, calling him a 'great pioneer' and 'an important figure in the English Blues scene'\n\nIn a statement, they said: 'It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home on July 22, 2024, surrounded by loving family.\n\n'Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\n\n'John Mayall gave us 90 years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.'\n\nRead More 'Father of British blues' John Mayall dies aged 90 surrounded by his family\n\nClapton, who was part of Mayall's Bluesbreakers band, posted a video on X, formerly Twitter, today saying he wanted to share a 'few words'.\n\n'I want to say thank you chiefly for rescuing me from oblivion and God knows what,' he said.\n\nClapton explained as teenager starting out in the music industry, he wanted to 'quit music', but Mayall encouraged him to join his band.\n\n'I learned all that I really have to go on today in terms of technique, and desire to play, the kind of music I love to play,' he added.\n\n'He taught me that it was OK just to... play the music you wanted to play without crashing out or making anybody else like it, whether it mattered whether they like it or not, to listen to myself to my inner out motivations and he was my mentor, and as a surrogate father too, he taught me all I really know and gave me the courage and enthusiasm to express myself without fear or without limit.'\n\nIn a post on Instagram, Sir Mick explained that the Bluesbreakers' band leader had helped in 'ushering in a new era for the Stones', following the death of guitarist Brian Jones.\n\nSpeaking about Mayall's influence, Sir Mick's post read: 'So sad to hear of John Mayall's passing.\n\n'He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented young musicians, including Mick Taylor, who he recommended to me after Brian Jones died, ushering in a new era for the Stones.'\n\nA statement was released on John Mayall's official Instagram page today, announcing his passing\n\nMayall has been credited with helping develop a blues revival of the late 1960s and has been described as the 'father of British blues'. He is pictured here performing on the stage of the Miles Davis hall during the 42nd Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux, Switzerland\n\nThe musician (pictured in 1991) died at his home in California on Monday, surrounded by family, a statement on his Instagram page said\n\nJohn Mayall's Bluesbreakers: John Mayall, Eric Clapton, John McVie and Hughie Flint\n\nTaylor had played with Mayall's Bluesbreakers from 1966 to 1969, appearing on the albums Crusade, Diary of a Band and Bare Wires, as well as on his 1968 solo album Blues From Laurel Canyon.\n\nHe then joined the Stones in 1969, playing on parts of Let It Bleed and making his first full appearance on the single Honky Tonk Women.\n\nTaylor helped to introduce a heavier blues sound to the Stones, and played on some of the band's most acclaimed albums such as Sticky Fingers and Exile On Main St, before leaving the group in December 1974.\n\nRonnie Wood said he was 'sad to hear about the death of my friend' and lauded Mayall as 'an important figure in the English Blues scene'.\n\n'He nurtured the talent of many great guitarists including Peter Green, @EricClapton and @MickTaylorInfo,' the guitarist wrote on X.\n\n'He was a walking encyclopaedia of American and English blues and a musical trailblazer for all of us. Thank you John, God bless.'\n\nFormer Genesis guitarist Steve Hackett said Mayall was a 'true champion of the blues'.\n\n'He remains a huge inspiration to me and legion of other musicians,' he wrote on X.\n\nA tribute to Mayall from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame cited the guitarist as a 'a major influence on rock and roll', after he had been inducted earlier this year.\n\nA statement from the hall of fame read: '2024 Inductee John Mayall was the godfather of British blues.\n\n'As a singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and bandleader, Mayall displayed a talent for mentoring gifted young musicians, many of whom he recruited for his groundbreaking band the Bluesbreakers.\n\nMick Taylor, former lead guitarist of the John Mayall's Bluesbreakers, replaced Brian Jones as the new member of the Rolling Stones. Pictured: The Stones in Hyde Park, London (from left to right: Charlie Watts, Mick Taylor, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Bill Wyman)\n\nMayall performing on stage in 1979\n\n'With a rugged individuality and distinctive voice and style, he made visionary recordings that expanded the reach of the blues without ever watering them down.\n\n'Mayall exerted a major influence on rock and roll, inspiring countless musicians and fans with a lifetime's worth of unforgettable and influential music.'\n\nAmong other recruits to the Bluesbreakers were guitarist Peter Green, bassists Jack Bruce and John McVie, and drummer Aynsley Dunbar.\n\nAmerican blues rock guitarist Joe Bonamassa shared a number of his album covers and a picture of himself with Mayall on social media and wrote: 'Rest in Peace my friend.'\n\nHe added the Union flag and a broken heart emoji.\n\nMayall, who was born in Macclesfield and grew up in Cheadle, Greater Manchester, formed the Bluesbreakers in the early 1960s.\n\nHe has been credited with helping develop a blues revival of the late 1960s and has been described as the 'father of British blues'.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers started out playing at the Marquee Club -- a small and relatively cheap club -- situated at the heart of London's West End.\n\nIn 1964, Mayall obtained his first record date with producer Ian Samwell. The band recorded two tracks: 'Crawling Up a Hill' and 'Mr James'.\n\nBut it wasn't until April 1965 when former Yardbirds guitarist Eric Clapton replaced Roger Dean, that Mayall's career really took off.\n\nIn 1965, with Eric Clapton as their new guitar player, the Bluesbreakers began attracting considerable attention.\n\nJohn Mayall poses during an interview in Madrid, Spain, on February 13 2017\n\nPictured: Klaus Voormann, John Mayall, Joni Mitchell, Debby Chesher and Commander Cody during the promotion for the 'Starart' book that included art works by them and other musicians\n\nEnglish Blues and Rock musician John Mayall performing onstage at Greenwich Village's Bottom Line nightclub in 1979\n\nWhen Clapton left that summer on a jaunt to Greece, Peter Green -- founder of Fleetwood Mac -- took his place, while Jack Bruce -- of the rock band Cream -- played bass. In November 1965 Clapton returned, and Green departed.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers has been considered a training ground for other major musicians including John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac, Mick Taylor who played with the Rolling Stones, Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\nAlthough he admitted in an interview with The Guardian that he had 'managed to pick out some pretty special people'.\n\n'I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band - who can be good friends of mine,' Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. 'It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.'\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s.\n\n'I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,' he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. 'I'm still an underground performer.'\n\nAlthough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s. He is pictured on stage during the 42nd Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux\n\nMayall performing with the Bluesbreakers at the Deutsche Museum in Munich, West Germany, on January 21, 1970\n\nMayall's father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall once said: 'The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favourite pub was.'\n\nHe learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right -- so 'I wouldn't get all tangled up'.\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice.\n\nAided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album Blues Alone.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands.\n\nMayall's 1968 album Blues from Laurel Canyon signalled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall a low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again.\n\nMayall pictured during a concert in Milan in 2015\n\nMayall performing with his band the Bluesbreakers in Munich in 1969. The influential band was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars\n\nIn 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall had a Grammy nomination for Wake Up Call which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He also received a second nomination in 2022 for his album The Sun Is Shining Down.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nHe was made an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe is survived by his six children - Gaz, Jason, Red, Ben, Zak and Samson - seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8240311705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:38:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:38:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:38:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/john-mayall-blues-legend-dead-obituary-1235066448/", "title": "John Mayall, Legendary Pioneer of British Blues, Dead at 90", "body": "Blues and rock musician John Mayall -- the \"godfather of British blues\" -- died at age 90 on Monday.\n\n\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by his loving family,\" his family confirmed in a statement Tuesday. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\" A cause of death was not immediately revealed.\n\n\"John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain,\" the statement continued, sharing that he was \"surrounded with love\" by his ex-wives Pamela and Maggie, his secretary Jane, and his close friends. \"Keep on playing the blues somewhere, John. We love you,\" his family wrote.\n\nMayall is credited as being a blues pioneer in England in the late Sixties. His band, The Bluesbreakers, once included the likes of Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, and Mick Taylor. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame is set to induct Mayall in October, after the organization's committee granted him the Musical Influence Award, alongside Alexis Korner and Big Mama Thornton.\n\nMayall told Rolling Stone in 2021, as he turned 88, that he had decided to \"hang up my road shoes,\" though he promised to release another album, The Sun Is Shining Down.\n\nThe obituary post pointed to an interview Mayall did with The Guardian, sharing how he connected with blues because of its \"raw honesty, connection, and community.\" The statement also shared a quote from Mayall about the future of blues that read, \"To be honest, I don't think anyone really knows exactly what it is. {"uri": "8240339211", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "01:12:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T01:12:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T01:12:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.americanbluesscene.com/2024/07/john-mayall-godfather-of-british-blues-dies-aged-90/", "title": "John Mayall, Godfather of British Blues, Dies Aged 90", "body": "\"I've had a very interesting life,\" blues legend John Mayall once told American Blues Scene. \"And I think, being a musician, you are able to put your experiences into music. That's the nice thing about the blues is you can tell your stories through words and music. You know, there's never any shortage of things that happen to a person. And you can put those experiences into music.\"\n\nThe death was confirmed in a statement on Mr. Mayall's official Facebook page that read, \"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by loving family. Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nBorn in Cheshire, England, Mayall developed an early penchant for American jazz and blues, teaching himself to play the piano, guitar, and harmonica. His friend Alexis Korner talked him into moving to London where he formed the Bluesbreakers. When Eric Clapton left the Yardbirds in 1965, Mayall jumped at the chance to hire him. The band's debut album, Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton, known as The Beano Album to aficionados, soon became a bestseller. After Clapton left the band to form Cream with bassist Jack Bruce, Mayall recruited Peter Green. When Green later left with McVie and Fleetwood to form the first incarnation of Fleetwood Mac, Mayall brought in Mick Taylor, who remained in the Bluesbreakers for about a year before joining the Rolling Stones.\n\nIn 1967, during his initial U.S. tour, Mr. Mayall found himself captivated by California. Two years later, he relocated to the Laurel Canyon area of Los Angeles, which was then burgeoning with a vibrant music scene. Transitioning away from the Bluesbreakers moniker, he released Blues From Laurel Canyon in 1968, despite having recorded it in England. This album marked a departure from his previous work.\n\nThe Turning Point, released in 1969, represented a significant shift in Mr. Mayall's musical direction. It was a live album that pioneered the \"unplugged\" concept within the rock genre by eschewing amplified instruments. Instead, the album featured acoustic guitars, bass, and saxophones, omitting drums entirely. One of the standout tracks was \"Room to Move,\" a lively shuffle tune that quickly became one of Mr. Mayall's most renowned compositions. This track showcased his ability to adapt and innovate within the evolving landscape of blues and rock music during that era.\n\nIn the 1980s, John Mayall underwent a significant personal transformation by quitting drinking. This period also saw him revive the Bluesbreakers, occasionally reuniting with notable musicians like Eric Clapton, Mick Taylor, and John McVie for concerts. Over the years, he collaborated with several standout guitarists including Harvey Mandel, Coco Montoya, and Walter Trout, all of whom contributed to the evolving sound of his groups.\n\nIn 2008, Mayall made the decision to retire the Bluesbreakers name, but this did not slow down his musical career. He continued to tour extensively and collaborated with prominent American blues artists such as Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, and Albert Collins. Critics continued to acclaim his work, with several of his later albums receiving high praise.\n\nOne notable album from this later period is Talk About That, released in 2016, which featured guitarist Joe Walsh. This album was particularly well-received, with many critics considering it among the best efforts of Mayall's extensive career. Throughout these decades, John Mayall's dedication to the blues genre and his ability to adapt and collaborate with a diverse range of musicians ensured his continued influence and relevance in the music world.\n\nMayall won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005. He was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class, along with Alexis Korner and Big Mama Thornton.", "source": {"uri": "americanbluesscene.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "American Blues {"uri": "2024-07-431537426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "03:22:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T03:22:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T03:16:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.nme.com/news/music/british-blues-pioneer-john-mayall-has-died-aged-90-3777318", "title": "British blues pioneer John Mayall has died, aged 90", "body": "Mayall was due to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall Of Fame in October\n\nPioneering British blues and rock musician John Mayall has died at the age on 90.\n\nMayall's passing was announced via his family on Facebook, writing in the early hours of July 23: \"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by loving family. Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nOften heralded as 'The Godfather of British Blues', Mayall was a singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist with a love of American blues and jazz and a keen sense for spotting young talent, often giving them a platform through his band the Blues Breakers.\n\nBorn in America, Mayall relocated to London in the early '60s and launched the Blues Breakers - then stylised as Bluesbreakers - in 1963, through which he pioneered the British blues and rock scene.\n\nDuring the 1960s, the group would include a revolving door of rock royalty - many of whom would go on to become icons in their own rights - such as Eric Clapton, Peter Green, Jack Bruce, John McVie, Mick Fleetwood, Aynsley Dunbar and future Rolling Stones guitarist Mick Taylor.\n\nIn the early 1970s, Mayall returned to America, where he would continue working with rising talents. Experimenting with elements of jazz, funk and rock into his blues sound, he had collaborated with the likes of Paul Butterfield, Patti Smith, Canned Heat's Larry Taylor and Harvey Mandel, Jesse Ed Davis, Rick Vito, Freebo, and more.\n\nIn 2005, Mayall was appointed as an OBE (Officer of the British Empire). He was due to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame at its ceremony in Cleveland this October.\n\nOver the course of his illustrious and lengthy career, Mayall recorded and released well over 30 albums - both as the member of a band, and as a solo artist - with his last recording coming in the form of 2022's 'The Sun Is Shining Down'.\n\nFollowing the news of his death, several musicians have paid tribute to John Mayall.\n\nMayall's Bluesbreakers bandmate Walter Trout wrote on Facebook: \"He is and will always be my musical mentor, my greatest supporter, and an incredible talent. We just lost a giant. I loved him like a father, and I always will.\"", "source": {"uri": "nme.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NME Music News, Reviews, Videos, Galleries, Tickets and Blogs | NME.COM"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-07-431468063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T23:47:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/23/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.", "source": {"uri": blues\u00b4 John Mayall was 'major influence on...", "body": "Blues pioneer John Mayall has been remembered as \"a major influence on rock and roll\" following his death at the age of 90.\n\nThe musician's influential band, the Bluesbreakers, was a launching pad for stars including Eric Clapton and Mick Fleetwood.\n\nHe died at his home in California on Monday surrounded by his family, a statement on his Instagram page said.\n\nA tribute from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, which inducted Mayall earlier this year, said: \"2024 Inductee John Mayall was the godfather of British blues.\n\n\"As a singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and bandleader, Mayall displayed a talent for mentoring gifted young musicians, many of whom he recruited for his groundbreaking band the Bluesbreakers.\n\n\"With a rugged individuality and distinctive voice and style, he made visionary recordings that expanded the reach of the blues without ever watering them down.\n\nBlues pioneer John Mayall has died in California at the age of 90 (Ian West/PA)\n\n\"Mayall exerted a major influence on rock and roll, inspiring countless musicians and fans with a lifetime's worth of unforgettable and influential music.\"\n\nAmong other recruits to the Bluesbreakers were guitarists Peter Green and Mick Taylor, bassists Jack Bruce and John McVie, and drummer Aynsley Dunbar.\n\nAmerican blues rock guitarist Joe Bonamassa shared a number of his album covers and a picture of himself with Mayall on social media and wrote: \"Rest in Peace my friend.\"\n\nHe added the Union flag and a broken heart emoji.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said: \"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by his loving family.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nIt added: \"Keep on playing the blues somewhere, John. {"uri": "8241770272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:24:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:24:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:22:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2024/07/24/John-Mayall-dies-British-blues/3051721842477/", "title": "'Godfather of British Blues'  John Mayall dies at 90 in California - UPI.com", "body": "\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home,\" the statement said. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\"\n\nJagger's statement on his Instagram account said, \"So sad to hear of John Mayall's passing. He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented young musicians, including Mick Taylor - who he recommended to me after Brian Jones died - ushering in a new era for the Stones.\"\n\nIn 1963 Mayall's band the Bluesbreakers, formerly the Blues Syndicate, started performing regularly at London's Marquee Club.\n\nHis first album, John Mayall plays Mayall, was recorded live at West Hampstead R&B Club.\n\nWhile that first recording was not a commercial success. Mayall added Eric Clapton to his band after Clapton left the Yardbirds, releasing the 1966 album Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton.\n\nMayall is in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and his Bluesbreakers band over the years included not only Clapton but also their Stones' Mick Taylor and several members of the future Fleetwood Mac, including John McVie and Mick Fleetwood.\n\nMayall's Instagram account statement added, \"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home... surrounded by his loving family.\"\n\nAfter the Bluesbreakers formed in 1963, the band charted nearly 20 albums from 1968-75.\n\nAmong the band's biggest sellers was 1969's The Turning Point that went gold peaking on the charts at No. 32. The band's best-selling U.S. album was 1970's USA Union that reached No. 22.\n\nMayall was known as \"the Godfather of British Blues.\" Born in 1933, Mayall played guitar, piano and harmonica in his youth.\n\nHe studied graphic design at Manchester Art School, moved to London and formed the Bluesbreakers while in his early thirties.\n\nIn comments to The Guardian in 2014, Mayall said, \"The blues fitted in with the early '60s, the social way of life at the time. It happened here, rather than in America, because at the time, the scene in America was racially segregated-over there, never the twain would meet.\"\n\nMayall formed the Bluesbreakers with McVie, Peter Ward and others after moving to London in 1963.\n\nQueen Elizabeth II made him an OBE, Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire in 2005. He was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame in 2016 and joined the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2024.", "source": {"uri": "upi.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UPI"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-432261052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:04:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:04:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:55:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.cleveland.com/news/2024/07/pioneering-british-blues-musician-rock-hall-inductee-dies.html", "title": "Pioneering British blues musician, Rock Hall inductee dies", "body": "Musician John Mayall, who was known as the \"Godfather of British Blues,\" died Monday at his home in California, his family announced. He was 90.\n\nNo cause of death was given.\n\n\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by loving family,\" the Mayall family said in a statement. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\n\n\"We, the Mayall family, cannot thank his fans and long-list of bandmembers enough for the support and love we were blessed to experience secondhand over the last six decades. Keep on playing the blues somewhere, John. We love you,\" the statement added.\n\nBorn November 29, 1933, in Cheshire, England, Mayall is credited with being one of the most influential rock musicians of the 1960s and 1970s.\n\nA vocalist and songwriter who also played guitar, keyboards and harmonica, Mayall was the frontman for English blues rock band John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers, which formed in London in 1963. The Bluesbreakers included and helped launched the careers of legendary musicians such as Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood, Peter Green, John McVie and Mick Taylor.\n\nMayall's final performance was March 26, 2022, at the Couch House in San Juan Capistrano, California.\n\nEarlier this year, Mayall was announced as a member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Class of 2024, which will hold its induction ceremony in October in Cleveland. Mayall will posthumously receive the Music Influence Award alongside fellow British blues legend Alexis Korner and American blues-rock pioneer Big Mama Thornton.\n\nMayall is survived by his six children, Gaz, Jason, Red, Ben, Zak and Samson; seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. He is also \"surrounded with love\" by his previous wives, Maggie and Pamela, as well as his devoted secretary, Jane, and his close friends, the Mayall family said.", "source": {"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757937", "eventUri": "eng-9757937", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2627450980392156, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8240323956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:55:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:55:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:54:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/article_85084225-ac06-5562-994e-5144335eb683.html", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90", "body": "AP\n\nLONDON (AP) -- John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nHe is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the late 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat; and Jon Mark and John Almond, who went on to form the Mark-Almond Band.\n\nPeople are also reading... Update: Distillery building damaged by fire after Highway 29 crash in Napa Report: Visit Napa Valley staff allege toxic comments, secrecy by CEO Gallagher Vallejo man dies, Napan hurt in Highway 29 crash Napa City Council votes to sell Dwight Murray Plaza, other downtown land to developers Fight between Le Petit Elephant and Alta Heights neighbors gets personal Ira C. Smith, KVON/KVYN radio sports director since 1976, dies at age 88 2023-24 Napa County Boys Soccer Player of the Year: Avi\u00f1a did it all for first-time section champ Calistoga Kevin Courtney, Napa Journal: My street is getting a major luxury upgrade Update: Ridge Fire in Lake County is 15% contained; evacuation orders in effect CHP: K-9 sniffs out 70 pounds of meth during Napa traffic stop Four arrested after Napa grocery robbery, police say Restaurant owners, workers urge action against unpermitted food vending in Napa Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa's new caf\u00e9 and bakery $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Napa County acquiring land for flood wall project\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nA small but enduring thing. Though Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.\n\n\"I've never had a hit record, I never won a Grammy Award, and Rolling Stone has never done a piece about me,\" he said in an interview with the Santa Barbara Independent in 2013. \"I'm still an underground performer.\"\n\nKnown for his blues harmonica and keyboard playing, Mayall had a Grammy nomination, for \"Wake Up Call\" which featured guest artists Buddy Guy, Mavis Staples, Mick Taylor and Albert Collins. He received a second nomination in 2022 for his album \"The Sun Is Shining Down.\" He also won official recognition in Britain with the award of an OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire) in 2005.\n\nHe was selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class and his 1966 album \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" is considered one of the best British blues albums.\n\nMayall once was asked if he kept playing to meet a demand, or simply to show he could still do it.\n\n\"Well, the demand is there, fortunately. But it's really for neither of those two things, it's just for the love of the music,\" he said in an interview with Hawaii Public Radio. \"I just get together with these guys and we have a workout.\"\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester in central England.\n\nSounding a note of the hard-luck bluesman, Mayall once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nHis father also played guitar and banjo, and his records of boogie-woogie piano captivated his teenage son.\n\nMayall said he learned to play the piano one hand at a time -- a year on the left hand, a year on the right, \"so I wouldn't get all tangled up.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe piano was his main instrument, though he also performed on guitar and harmonica, as well as singing in a distinctive, strained-sounding voice. Aided only by drummer Keef Hartley, Mayall played all the other instruments for his 1967 album, \"Blues Alone.\"\n\nMayall was often called the \"father of British blues,\" but when he moved to London in 1962 his aim was to soak up the nascent blues scene led by Alexis Korner and Cyril Davies. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Eric Burdon were among others drawn to the sound.\n\nThe Bluesbreakers drew on a fluid community of musicians who drifted in and out of various bands. Mayall's biggest catch was Clapton, who had quit the Yardbirds and joined he Bluesbreakers in 1965 because he was unhappy with the Yardbirds' commercial direction.\n\nMayall and Clapton shared a passion for Chicago blues, and the guitarist later remembered that Mayall had \"the most incredible collection of records I had ever seen.\"\n\nMayall tolerated Clapton's waywardness: He disappeared a few months after joining the band, then reappeared later the same year, sidelining the newly arrived Peter Green, then left for good in 1966 with Bruce to form Cream, which rocketed to commercial success, leaving Mayall far behind.\n\nClapton, interviewed for a BBC documentary on Mayall in 2003, confessed that \"to a certain extent I have used his hospitality, used his band and his reputation to launch my own career,\"\n\n\"I think he is a great musician. I just admire and respect his steadfastness,\" Clapton added.\n\nMayall encouraged Clapton to sing and urged Green to develop his song-writing abilities.\n\nMick Taylor, who succeeded Green as a Bluesbreaker in the late 1960s, valued the wide latitude which Mayall allowed his soloists.\n\n\"You'd have complete freedom to do whatever you wanted,\" Taylor said in a 1979 interview with writer Jas Obrecht. \"You could make as many mistakes as you wanted, too.\"\n\nMayall's 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon\" signaled a permanent move to the United States and a change in direction. He disbanded the Bluesbreakers and worked with two guitars and drums.\n\nThe following year he released \"The Turning Point,\" arguably his most successful release, with an atypical four-man acoustic lineup including Mark and Almond. \"Room to Move,\" a song from that album, was a frequent audience favorite in Mayall's later career.\n\nThe 1970s found Mayall at low ebb personally, but still touring and doing more than 100 shows a year.\n\n\"Throughout the '70s, I performed most of my shows drunk,\" Mayall said in an interview with Dan Ouellette for Down Beat magazine in 1990. One consequence was an attempt to jump from a balcony into a swimming pool that missed -- shattering one of Mayall's heels and leaving him with a limp.\n\n\"That was one incident that got me to stop drinking,\" Mayall said.\n\nIn 1982, he reformed the Bluesbreakers, recruiting Taylor and McVie, but after two years the personnel changed again. In 2008, Mayall announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nMayall and his second wife, Maggie, divorced in 2011 after 30 years of marriage. They had two sons.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree {"uri": "2024-07-431773485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:05:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:05:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:45:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/2024-07-24/father-of-british-blues-john-mayall-dies-peacefully-aged-90", "title": "'Father of British blues' John Mayall dies 'peacefully' aged 90", "body": "Mayall was a pioneering figure in the British blues movement credited with shaping its revival in the sixties\n\nThe 'father of British blues' John Mayall who helped start the music career of stars like Eric Clapton died \"peacefully\" aged 90.\n\nA statement on his Instagram said that the blues and rock musician died on July 22 surrounded by family.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" it wrote.\n\n\"John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nBorn in 1933 in Macclesfield, Cheshire, he learned piano, guitar, and harmonica at a young age.\n\nAfter serving three years in Korea, he attended art school in Manchester and helped form the band Powerhouse Four.\n\nMayall told the Guardian in 2014: \"The scene in America was racially segregated - over there, never the twain would meet.\n\n\"In Europe, however - not just England - the black blues began to be heard by an audience that was not listening to them in America. We discovered Elmore James, Freddie King, JB Lenoir, and they spoke to our feelings, our life stories and that was it. Hooked.\"\n\nThe Powerhouse Four would eventually lead to the formation of the Bluesbreakers.\n\nMayall sang and played guitar and keyboards in the Bluesbreakers. He recruited musicians like John McVie, a future Fleetwood Mac member.\n\nThe band debuted in 1964 and was the backing band for the Black American blues singer John Lee Hooker in the same year.\n\nMayall also played with blues legends such as Sonny Boy Williamson and T-Bone Walker, using his band to popularise blues in the UK with both covers and original songs.\n\nIn 1965, Eric Clapton joined the Bluesbreakers after leaving the Yardbirds, with their first sessions produced by a young Jimmy Page.\n\nClapton was briefly replaced by Peter Green, another future Fleetwood Mac star, and Jack Bruce played bass for a time. After Clapton returned, they recorded the hit album Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton in 1966.\n\n\"(Blues) is about - and it's always been about - that raw honesty with which [it expresses] our experiences in life, something which all comes together in this music, in the words as well. Something that is connected to us, common to our experiences,\" he told The Guardian.\n\nMayall moved to Los Angeles in 1969 and continued to lead bands, release dozens of albums and toured throughout the US and Europe into his late 80s.\n\nThe two-time Grammy-nominated artist was appointed an OBE (Officer of the British Empire) in 2005 and was recently inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.\n\nMayall is survived by six children, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.\n\nThe family statement ended by saying: \"We, the Mayall family, cannot thank his fans and long list of bandmembers enough for the support and love we were blessed to experience secondhand over the last six decades.\"", "source": {"uri": "itv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ITV Hub"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8240326586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:58:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:58:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:56:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/john-mayall-legendary-pioneer-british-003708173.html", "title": "John Mayall, Legendary Pioneer of British Blues, Dead at 90", "body": "\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by his loving family,\" his family confirmed in a statement Tuesday. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\" A cause of death was not immediately revealed.\n\nMore from Rolling Stone\n\n\"John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain,\" the statement continued, sharing that he was \"surrounded with love\" by his ex-wives Pamela and Maggie, his secretary Jane, and his close friends.\n\n\"Keep on playing the blues somewhere, John. We love you,\" his family wrote.\n\nMayall is credited as being a blues pioneer in England in the late Sixties. His band, The Bluesbreakers, once included the likes of Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, and Mick Taylor. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame is set to induct Mayall in October, after the organization's committee granted him the Musical Influence Award, alongside Alexis Korner and Big Mama Thornton, earlier this year.\n\nMayall was born in Cheshire, England, and loved American blues and jazz from an early age. He taught himself how to play piano, guitar, and harmonica before he moved to London to form the Blues Breakers, which included Clapton after he departed the Yardbirds.\n\nMayall's most-revered body of work was his debut LP, Blues Breakers, which Rolling Stone ranked No. 195 on its 500 Greatest Albums of All Time list in 2003. \"Ex-Yardbird Eric Clapton's solos here inspired his 'Clapton Is God' cult,\" read Rolling Stone's description. \"The band expertly covers Robert Johnson and Freddie King, and blows up Ray Charles' 'What'd I Say' with a long drum solo that predicts Cream.\"\n\nMayall released several albums through the Seventies after moving to Los Angeles in 1969. He was appointed Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II in 2005 and was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame in 2016.\n\nIn 2020, Mayall released a 1967 recording of the song \"Curly\" alongside the late Peter Green and John McVie. The recording was done for BBC Sessions before Green left the band to form Fleetwood Mac. The track was included in a box set titled The First Generation: 1966-1974, which dropped in 2021.\n\nThat year, Mayall told Rolling Stone, as he turned 88, that he had decided to \"hang up my road shoes,\" though he promised to release another album, The Sun Is Shining Down.\n\nThe obituary post pointed to an interview Mayall did with The Guardian, sharing how he connected with blues because of its \"raw honesty, connection, and community.\" The statement also shared a quote from Mayall about the future of blues that read, \"To be honest, I don't think anyone really knows exactly what it is. {"uri": "8241299367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:06:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:06:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:05:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/tributes-godfather-british-blues-john-29603740", "title": "Tributes to the 'godfather of British blues' John Mayall who has died aged 90", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nTributes have been paid to musician John Mayall, the Stockport-raised 'Godfather' of British Blues following his death. He was 90.\n\nThe musician's influential band, the Bluesbreakers, was a launching pad for stars including Eric Clapton and Mick Fleetwood. He died at his home in California on Monday surrounded by his family, a statement on his Instagram page said.\n\nThe Macclesfield-born Mayall would listen to his father's collection of jazz records at the family home Cheadle Hulme, inspiring a life-long passion for the Blues. He would spend hours listening to old 78s and he taught himself boogie-woogie piano, blues guitar and harmonica. It led to a career which saw him declared the godfather of British Blues.\n\nREAD MORE: Teenager fighting for life following smash between Audi and bike in Fallowfield\n\nA tribute from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, which inducted Mayall earlier this year, said: \"2024 Inductee John Mayall was the godfather of British blues.\n\n\"As a singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and bandleader, Mayall displayed a talent for mentoring gifted young musicians, many of whom he recruited for his groundbreaking band the Bluesbreakers.\n\n\"With a rugged individuality and distinctive voice and style, he made visionary recordings that expanded the reach of the blues without ever watering them down.\n\n\"Mayall exerted a major influence on rock and roll, inspiring countless musicians and fans with a lifetime's worth of unforgettable and influential music.\"\n\nAmong other recruits to the Bluesbreakers were guitarists Peter Green and Mick Taylor, bassists Jack Bruce and John McVie, and drummer Aynsley Dunbar.\n\nAmerican blues rock guitarist Joe Bonamassa shared a number of his album covers and a picture of himself with Mayall on social media and wrote: \"Rest in Peace my friend.\"\n\nHe added the Union flag and a broken heart emoji.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page said: \"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home yesterday, July 22, 2024, surrounded by his loving family.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors. John Mayall gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nIt added: \"Keep on playing the blues somewhere, John. We love you.\"\n\nMayall was made an OBE in 2005. {"uri": "8240416794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "02:46:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T02:46:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T02:44:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "http://mynewsla.com/orange-county/2024/07/23/longtime-la-resident-john-mayall-godfather-of-british-blues-dies-at-90/", "title": "Longtime LA Resident John Mayall, 'Godfather of British Blues,' Dies at 90 - MyNewsLA.com", "body": "John Mayall, the so-called \"Godfather of British blues\" who led the blues explosion of the mid-1960s and introduced the world to such guitar luminaries as Eric Clapton, Peter Green and Mick Taylor, as well as drummer Mick Fleetwood, all early members of his band John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers, has died at age 90, it was announced Tuesday.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death, saying only that the musician, singer and bandleader died Monday at his home in California surrounded by his family.\n\nMayall had a decades-long association with Los Angeles, naming a popular 1968 album \"Blues from Laurel Canyon,\" where he lived in a three-story hillside home for 10 years until a brush fire in September 1979 left only a charred foundation and a hand-painted swimming pool on the property. He remained in the area afterwards.\n\nMayall released more than three dozen albums during his career, remaining faithful to American blues music while showing an ear for talent, utilizing countless support players, many of whom eclipsed the leader with their own bands or as members of other highly successful groups.\n\nFor British blues guitarists of the 1960s, Mayall's band was a kind of finishing school. Introducing Clapton on the 1966 album, \"Blues Breakers with Eric Clapton,\" Mayall allowed his young side man to take center stage, giving birth to a guitar-heavy sound that dominated rock music for the next 20 years.\n\nClapton famously quit Mayall's band without notice after less than a year, replaced by Green, who left the Bluesbreakers shortly afterwards with drummer Fleetwood in tow to form the highly successful Fleetwood Mac, which was founded by Green.\n\nMayall next hired a teenage Taylor to fill the Bluesbreakers' closely watched guitar spot, and four albums later, Mayall's young prot\u00c3\u00a9g\u00c3\u00a9 departed to accept an offer from the Rolling Stones.\n\nIn the many bands he led, Mayall wrote songs, handled vocals, played harmonica, organ and guitar, and often produced his own album artwork. Although he usually remained true to American blues with little deviation, a drummerless jazz-inspired outfit he ran in the 1970s proved to be his most popular group since the days of the big name guitarists to whom he handed the spotlight. Yet he remained a draw in the clubs and at summer festivals around the world until his retirement from touring in 2022 after a final gig at The Coach House in San Juan Capistrano.\n\nMayall was born on Nov. 29, 1933 in Macclesfield, near Manchester, in central England. He once said, \"The only reason I was born in Macclesfield was because my father was a drinker, and that's where his favorite pub was.\"\n\nMayall was appointed as an Officer of the Order of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II in 2005. His selection as a recipient of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Musical Influence Award: was announced April 21. The two-time Grammy nominee will be inducted into the hall of fame posthumously Oct. 19.\n\nMayall is survived by two ex-wives, six children, Gaz, Jason, Red, Ben, Zak and Samson, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.", "source": {"uri": "mynewsla.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "My News LA"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", "type": {"uri": "8241886925", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:08:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:08:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.newdelhitimes.com/john-mayall-tireless-and-influential-british-blues-pioneer-dies-at-90/", "title": "John Mayall, tireless and influential British blues pioneer, dies at 90 - New Delhi Times - India's Only International Newspaper - Empowering Global Vision, Empathizing with India", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues musician whose influential band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood and many other superstars, has died. He was 90.\n\nA statement on Mayall's Instagram page announced his death Tuesday, saying the musician died Monday at his home in California. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" the post said.\n\nAmong this year's new members of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, he is credited with helping develop the English take on urban, Chicago-style rhythm and blues that played an important role in the blues revival of the 1960s. At various times, the Bluesbreakers included Eric Clapton and Jack Bruce, later of Cream; Mick Fleetwood, John McVie and Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac; Mick Taylor, who played five years with the Rolling Stones; and Harvey Mandel and Larry Taylor of Canned Heat.\n\nClapton and McVie both played on the 1966 release \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" which Rolling Stone magazine has ranked among the 500 greatest albums.\n\n\"He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented musicians,\" Mick Jagger wrote on X, adding that it was Mayall who recommended Taylor as a replacement in 1969 for founding Stones guitarist Brian Jones, \"ushering in a new era\" for the band.\n\nMayall protested in interviews that he was not a talent scout, but played for the love of the music he had first heard on his father's 78-rpm records.\n\n\"I'm a band leader and I know what I want to play in my band -- who can be good friends of mine,\" Mayall said in an interview with the Southern Vermont Review. \"It's definitely a family. It's a small kind of thing really.\"\n\nThough Mayall never approached the fame of some of his illustrious alumni, he was still performing in his late 80s, pounding out his version of Chicago blues. The lack of recognition rankled a bit, and he wasn't shy about saying so.", "source": {"uri": "newdelhitimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Delhi Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-431558587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "04:03:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T04:03:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T02:38:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_a1d07893-594b-55d3-9420-3c55983316b6.html", "title": "UK blues legend John Mayall dead at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues pioneer whose 1960s music collective the Bluesbreakers helped usher in a fertile period of rock and brought guitarists like Eric Clapton to prominence, has died at 90, his family said Tuesday.\n\nMayall, a singer and multi-instrumentalist who was dubbed \"the godfather of British blues,\" and whose open-door arrangement saw some of the greats in the genre hone their craft with him and his band, \"passed away peacefully in his California home\" on Monday, according to a statement posted on his Facebook page.\n\nIt did not state a cause of death.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" it said. \"John Mayall gave us 90 years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nMayall's influence on 1960s rock and beyond is enormous. Members of the Bluesbreakers eventually went on to join or form groups including Cream, Fleetwood Mac, the Rolling Stones and many more.\n\nAt age 30, Mayall moved to London from northern England in 1963. Sensing revolution in the air, he gave up his profession as a graphic designer to embrace a career in blues, the musical style born in Black America.\n\nHe teamed up with a series of young guitarists including Clapton, Peter Green, later of Fleetwood Mac, and Mick Taylor who helped form the Rolling Stones.\n\nIn the Bluesbreakers' debut album in 1966, \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" John Mayall enthralled music aficionados with a melding of soulful rock and gutsy, guitar-driven American blues featuring covers of tunes by Robert Johnson, Otis Rush and Ray Charles.\n\nThe blues music he was playing in British venues was \"a novelty for white England,\" he told AFP in 1997.\n\nThat album was a hit, catapulting Clapton to stardom and bringing a wave of popularity to a more raw and personal blues music.\n\nMayall moved to California in 1968 and toured America extensively in 1972.\n\nHe recorded a number of landmark albums in the 1960s including \"Crusade,\" \"A Hard Road,\" and \"Blues From Laurel Canyon.\" Dozens more followed in the 1970s and up to his latest, \"The Sun Is Shining Down,\" in 2022.\n\nMayall was awarded an OBE, an Officer of the Order of the British Empire, {"uri": "8241848279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:33:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:33:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:32:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.realitytvworld.com/news/godfather-of-british-blues--john-mayall-dies-at-90-in-california-50222633.php", "title": "'Godfather of British Blues'  John Mayall dies at 90 in California", "body": "British blues great John Mayall has died in California at the age of 90. Mick Jagger mourned Mayall's passing, calling him a great pioneer of British blues.\n\n\"It is with heavy hearts that we bear the news that John Mayall passed away peacefully in his California home,\" the statement said. \"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\"\n\nJagger's statement on his Instagram account said, \"So sad to hear of John Mayall's passing. He was a great pioneer of British blues and had a wonderful eye for talented young musicians, including Mick Taylor - who he recommended to me after Brian Jones died - ushering in a new era for the Stones.\"\n\nIn 1963 Mayall's band the Bluesbreakers, formerly the Blues Syndicate, started performing regularly at London's Marquee Club.\n\nWhile that first recording was not a commercial success. Mayall added Eric Clapton to his band after Clapton left the Yardbirds, releasing the 1966 album Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton.\n\nMayall is in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and his Bluesbreakers band over the years included not only Clapton but also their Stones' Mick Taylor and several members of the future Fleetwood Mac, including John McVie and Mick Fleetwood.\n\nAfter the Bluesbreakers formed in 1963, the band charted nearly 20 albums from 1968-75.\n\nAmong the band's biggest sellers was 1969's The Turning Point that went gold peaking on the charts at No. 32. The band's best-selling U.S. album was 1970's USA Union that reached No. 22.\n\nMayall was known as \"the Godfather of British Blues.\" Born in 1933, Mayall played guitar, piano and harmonica in his youth.\n\nHe studied graphic design at Manchester Art School, moved to London and formed the Bluesbreakers while in his early thirties.\n\nIn comments to The Guardian in 2014, Mayall said, \"The blues fitted in with the early '60s, the social way of life at the time. It happened here, rather than in America, because at the time, the scene in America was racially segregated-over there, never the twain would meet.\"\n\nQueen Elizabeth II made him an OBE, Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire in 2005. He was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame in 2016 and joined the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2024.", "source": {"uri": "realitytvworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Reality TV World"}, {"uri": "8241234365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:26:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:26:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:25:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://popculture.com/music/news/2024-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-inductee-dies-ahead-ceremony-john-mayall-was-90/", "title": "2024 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductee Dies Ahead of Ceremony: John Mayall Was 90", "body": "Often called the 'godfather of British blues,' the musician band the Bluesbreakers was a training ground for the likes of Eric Clapton, Mick Fleetwood, and more.\n\nJohn Mayall, the British musician known as the \"godfather of British blues\" who was recently selected for the 2024 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame class, has died. Mayall passed away at his home in California on Monday, July 22, according to a statement shared to his Instagram page Tuesday night. He was 90.\n\nMayall's cause of death was not disclosed, but the statement said \"health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors.\" It added that the rocker \"gave us ninety years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain,\" and his \"raw honesty, connection, community and playing of his will continue to affect the music and culture we experience today, and for generations to come.\"\n\nConsidered to be \"the godfather of British blues,\" Mayall is credited with helping develop the English take on Chicago-style rhythm and blues. Born in the town of Macclesfield in Cheshire in November 1933, Mayall was drawn to the sound of the blues musicians from the Mississippi Delta at an early age. He told The Guardian in 2014, \"[It has] always been about that raw honesty with which [it expresses] our experiences in life, something which all comes together in this music, in the words as well. Something that is connected to us, common to our experiences. To be honest, I don't think anyone really knows exactly what it is. I just can't stop playing it.\"\n\nAfter completing a George Formby Teach Yourself Ukulele course and teaching himself to play piano as a teen, per the BBC, Mayall formed the Powerhouse Four in 1956, later going on to join a band called Blues Syndicate in 1962. The band was heavily influenced by Alexis Korner, who eventually persuaded Mayall to move to London, where he founded the Bluesbreakers in 1963. Over the years, the Bluesbreakers' members included Eric Clapton, Peter Green, Jack Bruce, John McVie, Mick Fleetwood, Aynsley Dunbar, and future Rolling Stone Mick Taylor, according to Deadline. The Bluesbreakers was not only a commercial force in the Swinging '60s UK, with five Top 10 LPs from 1966-70, but also a success in the U.S., where the group charted nearly 20 albums from 1968-75, including The Turning Point (1969), which went gold and peaked at No. 32.\n\nIn 1969, Mayall relocated to the U.S., where he continued to front bands, eventually recruiting Taylor and McVie to reform the Bluesbreakers in 1982. In 2008, he announced that he was permanently retiring the Bluesbreaker name, and in 2013 he was leading the John Mayall Band.\n\nThe musician released dozens of albums and scored two Grammy nominations - Best Contemporary Blues Album in 1993 for Wake Up Call, and Best Traditional Blues Album in 2022 for The Sun Is Shining Down. He was named an Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (OBE) by Queen Elizabeth II in 2005 and inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame in 2016. He was recently announced as a 2024 inductee into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, which said, \"continually expanding the reach of the blues without ever watering them down, John Mayall has had a major influence on rock music. He is the Godfather of British Blues.\"", "source": {"uri": "popculture.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Celebrity"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Mayall", {"uri": "2024-07-431878208", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:36:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:36:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:01:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wfxg.com/news/uk-blues-legend-john-mayall-dead-at-90/article_68ef7ac5-4a4b-5582-be48-c86e55678c34.html", "title": "UK blues legend John Mayall dead at 90", "body": "John Mayall, the British blues pioneer whose 1960s music collective the Bluesbreakers helped usher in a fertile period of rock and brought guitarists like Eric Clapton to prominence, has died at 90, his family said Tuesday.\n\nMayall, a singer and multi-instrumentalist who was dubbed \"the godfather of British blues,\" and whose open-door arrangement saw some of the greats in the genre hone their craft with him and his band, \"passed away peacefully in his California home\" on Monday, according to a statement posted on his Facebook page.\n\nIt did not state a cause of death.\n\n\"Health issues that forced John to end his epic touring career have finally led to peace for one of this world's greatest road warriors,\" it said. \"John Mayall gave us 90 years of tireless efforts to educate, inspire and entertain.\"\n\nMayall's influence on 1960s rock and beyond is enormous. Members of the Bluesbreakers eventually went on to join or form groups including Cream, Fleetwood Mac, the Rolling Stones and many more.\n\nAt age 30, Mayall moved to London from northern England in 1963. Sensing revolution in the air, he gave up his profession as a graphic designer to embrace a career in blues, the musical style born in Black America.\n\nHe teamed up with a series of young guitarists including Clapton, Peter Green, later of Fleetwood Mac, and Mick Taylor who helped form the Rolling Stones.\n\nStones frontman Mick Jagger said Mayall was \"a great pioneer of British blues.\"\n\nHe \"had a wonderful eye for talented young musicians, including Mick Taylor -- who he recommended to me after Brian Jones died -- ushering in a new era for the Stones,\" Jagger wrote on social media platform X.\n\nIn the Bluesbreakers' debut album in 1966, \"Blues Breakers With Eric Clapton,\" John Mayall enthralled music aficionados with a melding of soulful rock and gutsy, guitar-driven American blues featuring covers of tunes by Robert Johnson, Otis Rush and Ray Charles.\n\nThe blues music he was playing in British venues was \"a novelty for white England,\" he told AFP in 1997.\n\nThat album was a hit, catapulting Clapton to stardom and bringing a wave of popularity to a more raw and personal blues music.\n\nMayall moved to California in 1968 and toured America extensively in 1972.\n\nHe recorded a number of landmark albums in the 1960s including \"Crusade,\" \"A Hard Road,\" and \"Blues From Laurel Canyon.\" Dozens more followed in the 1970s and up to his latest, \"The Sun Is Shining Down,\" in 2022.\n\nMayall was awarded an OBE, an Officer of the Order of the British Empire, in 2005.\n\nmlm/jgc/rsc/mtp", "source": {"uri": "wfxg.com", "dataType":
